|I think you can only use the docUrl tag to point to an HTML file in a Qt help file (.qch). For example: docUrl=&quot;qthelp://org.qt-project.qtc
reator/doc/creator-app-tutorial-bb10.html&quot;

You would need to create a .qdoc file in qt-creator/doc/src/qnx (for example, creator-app-tutorial-bb10.qdoc) with the &quot;\page creator-app-tutorial-bb10.html&quot; command. Also, you would need to add the topic to the TOC in doc/src/qtcreator.qdoc and to the Tutorials topic to be able to access it also from the Qt Creator Manual contents.

For more information, see:  http://doc-snapshot.qt-project.org/qtcreator-extending/qtcreator-documentation.html

|These are incomplete sentences with an ellipsis in the beginning. The form of the verb depends on the part of the sentence that has been omitted.

To test whether the verb should be in third person singular form, try adding &quot;This option&quot; to the beginning of the tooltip in your mind. If the tooltip is still grammatically correct, you can add the &quot;s&quot;.

However, if you would need to add &quot;Select this option to&quot;, for the resulting tooltip to be grammatically correct, the verb should be in first person singular form (without the &quot;s&quot;).

So, here the question is: &quot;Does the option do the inserting, like a function would, or does it just specify that something else will do the inserting, when necessary?&quot;

|All the screen shots in the manual are dithered on purpose: 

&quot;To make the images look similar regardless of the operating system they were taken on, you are asked to adjust their size to 75%. This makes the screen shots hard to read, but they are provided more as reassurance for users that they are in the correct place in the UI than as an actual source of information. To make sure that no important information is lost, always place example values also in the text.&quot; 

http://doc-snapshots.qt.io/qtcreator-extending/qtcreator-documentation.html#taking-screen-shots

There is a task to change the guidelines to make the screenshots crisp and readable, but there has not been much progress in that matter:

https://bugreports.qt.io/browse/QTCREATORBUG-16076

Please vote for the task and add your comments there.

|&quot;Alternatively&quot; and &quot;also&quot; don't go together. If you want to say that only one of these ways should be implemented at a time, use &quot;alternatively&quot;. If you want to say that both ways can be implemented at the same time, use &quot;in addition&quot;.

|&quot;added into&quot; or &quot;added to&quot;
|Consistency is a huge problem for cross-platform, because the platforms all use their own terminology. I usually try to use the terminology for the particular platform in platform-specific sections. That makes it easier for the readers to create connections with the documentation provided by the platform itself (that is, to understand what we are talking about).

In regard to &quot;Products&quot;, this particular instance should be upper case, because this is a section title and the Qt style is to use book style capitalization in section headings. In text, it is fine to write it in lower case.

|QString::sprintf() is obsolete since Qt 5.7. Suggested alternatives are asprintf(), arg(), and QTextStream, but their docs did not have much information about the format.

\section1 Title with Capitalization
|This was removed and should not be brought back. Instead, an include file now adds instructions for running examples to each example doc.
|Remove up to here.
|\deprecated builds the documentation, and places it in an &quot;Obsolete Functions&quot; topic, whereas \internal causes the documentation not to be printed at all, but suppresses a QDoc warning for missing documentation. Therefore, using both at the same time does not make much sense. I used \internal and removed the documentation, because that would make most sense if this signal is actually never emitted.
|Here, I completely removed the documentation, because QDoc builds the documentation based on the QDoc commands used and does not print errors or warnings.
|Done

|I don't remember when this changed, but in Qt Creator 3.1 and later, you actually select the device when you run the application. The Device field just shows &quot;Android Device&quot;.
|You don't have to do this anymore. You just select the device from a list of connected devices (and virtual devices). You can also select a check box to use the selected device every time you run the application during a Qt Creator session.
|In the License Information topic, you have the following link that is broken: http://qt.digia.com/Products/Qt-Enterprise-Embedded. But maybe it needs to be changed there and not added here.
|Some of the entries emphasize the noun by placing it first and others emphasize the action by placing it first. Pick one and follow it. For features, it would seem more natural to start with the noun.

The UI text looks fine.
|Patch Set 2:

The guideline for constructing window titles is to keep it consistent with the menu item or button name that opens the window: &quot;Use the menu item or button name as the dialog name. You can also combine the menu item or button name and the name of the object that is managed in the dialog. For example, the Add button in the Documentation options opens the Add Documentation dialog.&quot;

http://doc-snapshot.qt-project.org/qtcreator-extending/qtcreator-ui-text.html

So, if this dialog opens from a &quot;Select Change&quot; or &quot;Select&quot; button, then this dialog title would follow the guidelines.
|Patch Set 2:

Then maybe &quot;Apply Actions on Commits&quot;, as that would describe what is happening in the dialog. We also seem to have a &quot;Select a Git Commit&quot; dialog with the same buttons:

http://qt-project.org/doc/qtcreator-3.0/creator-version-control.html


It seems like a bit misleading name (could also be  &quot;Apply Actions on Commits&quot;). How is that different from the dialog that you are adding the title for?

|Patch Set 3: (5 inline comments)

This topic should be structured so that the general information that applies to both online and offline installers is at the top. For example, the components that can be installed and the supported platforms. Maybe just a link to the supported platforms, though, as they are already listed in another topic. The online and offline sections should only contain information specific to that type of installer. Specifically, describe the benefits of both to help users decide which one they should choose.

Also, please check that you use terminology consistently. In many places topics that are not tutorials are listed as tutorials, which I find confusing.
|Patch Set 3:

This is what we had for the Qt 4 SDK:

You can download Qt 5 from xxx. The site provides download links for all supported development platforms. You can either choose to use the online installer or to directly download the installation package on a media for installation on a computer later.

We recommend that you use the online installer if you have reliable network access, because it provides you with automatic updates to installed content and easy access to all content that is added later. If you use the offline installer, you must check for updates yourself.

|Change has been successfully cherry-picked as e6fcde78cd2c5750d61ecaa8a61dfe61e31da414.
|Patch Set 1:

Are the spaces used for layout? Isn't that bad?
|Patch Set 1: (26 inline comments)

Some messages still contain single quotes. Mostly if the variable is not of the format &quot;%n&quot; or there is something between n and the end quote.

The following fixes could be made as a part of a follow-up commit:

- Where possible, move the variable to the end of the message and separate it from the rest of the message with a colon. This way, the quotes are not needed.
- Add full stops to the end of all messages. However, if the full stop might be misunderstood as being part of a variable value, you can either leave it out or place the variable value within quotes.
- Fix other punctuation issues. Mostly, commas should be colons or colons should be full stops.
- Fix typos.
- Use &quot;Error&quot; and &quot;Warning&quot; consistently. Now, they are sometimes written in all caps, sometimes with an initial capital. Sometimes a plugin name or some other identifier is included, sometimes not.

|Patch Set 3:

The text changes look good. Did you optimize the images? Please follow the guidelines here: http://doc-snapshot.qt-project.org/qtcreator-extending/qtcreator-documentation.html

If the image quality suffers notably, though, don't optimize.
|Patch Set 3:

The menu text font size in qmlvideofx-camera-glow.png looks huge, compared with the other images.
|Patch Set 3:

The guideline is to use 1024x768 resolution and then scale the images to 75%. You'd need to check how well that works for your setup. Scaling would be a good idea if the image quality does not degrade too much.

|Patch Set 4:

I'll change the copyrights for the existing files as a separate patch.

Is this what we would like to have in the docs? If you would only want to list IFW classes, we could list the files that contain them in the value of sourcedirs.

Currently, QDoc prints loads of errors and warnings that we might want to fix. Most of them are probably caused by missing documentation. You can get rid of those errors by using the \internal command for a class or function.

Also, some non-existent QDoc tags seem to be currently used. Supported QDoc commands are listed here: 

http://doc-snapshot.qt-project.org/qdoc/27-qdoc-commands-alphabetical.html
|Patch Set 4:

You run make install_global_docs in qtbase. The instructions are here:

https://qt-project.org/wiki/Building_Qt_Documentation

|Patch Set 9:

(1 comment)
|Patch Set 10: Code-Review+2

Thanks!
|Patch Set 10:

Sorry, but Tobias is right. You should use sentence-style capitalization for messages. The rules are a bit confusing, I know. You can find them here:

http://doc-snapshot.qt-project.org/qtcreator-extending/qtcreator-ui-text.html

Basically, use book-style capitalization only for:

- Titles (window, dialog, group box, tab, list view columns, and so on)
- Functions (menu items, buttons)
- Selectable items (combobox items, listbox items, tree list items, and so on)
|Patch Set 10:

(2 comments)

- Text area background color is grey
- The table background color is grey and there are no table borders

- Lists are not bulleted
- Nested lists are not nested
- code font is wrong

|Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2
|Patch Set 4:

I Googled this, and found 6 hits for &quot;in Win 7 onwards&quot; and 1.310 for &quot;from Win 7 onwards&quot;. 

In the dictionaries that define &quot;onwards&quot;, it is said to specify time and used with &quot;from&quot;: 

http://dictionary.cambridge.org/de/worterbuch/britisch/onwards
http://www.thefreedictionary.com/onwards

In Qt documentation, we use &quot;since&quot;.

|Patch Set 1:

Please check whether you introduced QDoc errors and fix them.
|Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

You'll need to take a closer look at the Qt Designer docs and related examples to see that you don't break anything.

For example, I think you'd need to modify the 3rd text paragraph here, before the first snippet:

http://doc-snapshots.qt.io/qt5-5.5/qtdesigner-customwidgetplugin-example.html

Also, if this is a new module, it would need to appear somewhere in the list of Qt modules here:

http://doc-snapshots.qt.io/qt5-5.5/qtmodules.html

Also, you're introducing the following QDoc warnings:

QtDesigner: WARNING: .../qt5/qttools/src/designer/src/lib/uilib/abstractformbuilder.h includes uilib_global.h when it should include QtDesigner/uilib_global.h
QtDesigner: WARNING: .../qt5/qttools/src/designer/src/lib/uilib/formbuilder.h includes uilib_global.h when it should include QtDesigner/uilib_global.h
QtDesigner: WARNING: .../qt5/qttools/src/designer/src/lib/uilib/formbuilder.h includes abstractformbuilder.h when it should include QtDesigner/abstractformbuilder.h

The docs for these classes are still generated under Qt Designer C++ Classes. Should they now be listed under the new module? Here is a checklist for adding docs for a new module:

http://wiki.qt.io/Checklist-for-Adding-Documentation-for-a-New-Module
|Patch Set 1:

If the text no longer makes sense after you change the implementation, it is &quot;doc breakage&quot; even if the docs could still be built and would *look correct*. Leaving it to a follow-up change is dangerous, because what if nobody ever makes the follow-up change?
|Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

Hmm, as Ossi is moving the files, maybe it is actually better to make the doc changes in a separate patch, so that they will be easier to follow.
|Patch Set 1:

Everything seems to still get built. Usually, you would put the qdoc files in a doc folder, though. That would then also contain a qddocconf file for the module, but according to Topi we don't need one here.

The link to the Qt Designer module is now broken from the All Qt Modules page (here, it still works: http://doc-snapshots.qt.io/qt5-5.5/qtmodules.html), but I don't know whether your changes are to blame.

|Patch Set 1:

The rule is &quot;Place three full stops (...) at the end of menu item names that open a dialog requiring user action.&quot;

If the command executes the action without additional input from the user, you don't need the three dots. I'm not sure what all the above do.

http://doc-snapshots.qt.io/qtcreator-extending/qtcreator-ui-text.html

Some changes here break the docs:

|Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

This is a good change. However, try to avoid using \code within tables, because long code lines add a scroll bar below the table in the HTML (when using the new online template to build the docs). Use \c instead, or make the code lines short.

|Patch Set 1:

I think you'd need to write the whole tooltip in HTML if you want to use tags in it. For example, in \src\plugins\debugger\debuggersourcepathmappingwidget.cpp:

    setTitle(tr(&quot;Source Paths Mapping&quot;));
    setToolTip(tr(&quot;&lt;html&gt;&lt;head/&gt;&lt;body&gt;&lt;p&gt;Mappings of source file folders to &quot;
                  &quot;be used in the debugger can be entered here.&lt;/p&gt;&quot;
                  &quot;&lt;p&gt;This is useful when using a copy of the source tree &quot;
                  &quot;at a location different from the one &quot;
                  &quot;at which the modules where built, for example, while &quot;
                  &quot;doing remote debugging.&lt;/p&gt;&quot;
                  &quot;&lt;p&gt;If source is specified as a regular expression by starting it with an &quot;
                  &quot;open parenthesis, Qt Creator matches the paths in the ELF with the &quot;
                  &quot;regular expression to automatically determine the source path.&lt;/p&gt;&quot;
                  &quot;&lt;p&gt;Example: &lt;b&gt;(/home/.*/Project)/KnownSubDir -&gt; D:\\Project&lt;/b&gt; will &quot;
                  &quot;substitute ELF built by any user to your local project directory.&lt;/p&gt;&quot;
                  &quot;&lt;/body&gt;&lt;/html&gt;&quot;));
|Patch Set 1:

Hmm, if we start actively changing these, we should pick a consistent way of doing it.
|Patch Set 1:

I vote for using &lt;html&gt;, too.

For QML types, yes. For C++ classes, you still write &quot;class&quot;. As a rule, if the documentation contains the \qmltype command, use &quot;type&quot;, if it contains the \class command, use &quot;class&quot;.

|Patch Set 1: Sanity-Review+1
|Change has been successfully cherry-picked
|Patch Set 1:

Can you check that I got these right? The rules are:

- Add a colon after field labels (no colons after check box labels or titles)
- Use book style capitalization for titles and for options in combo boxes
- Use sentence style capitalization for labels


For the rules, see: http://doc-snapshots.qt.io/qtcreator-extending/qtcreator-ui-text.html

Also, we have a small tool you can use to check how you need to capitalize a phrase when using book style caps.

|Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

Looks good and can be built correctly. Two general comments, though:

1) Usually, module names are written with a space in the documentation. According to the guidelines, the module name should be 'Qt SCXML':

https://wiki.qt.io/Spelling_Module_Names_in_Qt_Documentation

2) The general descriptions in this topic, including this new text, should be moved to an 'Overview' topic.

|Patch Set 5:

I don't think that adding the term &quot;Context Specific&quot; helps much here. Maybe you could specify the context here. These are &quot;Debugger Views&quot;, right?
|Patch Set 5:

You can either have a submenu for the context-sensitive views (could be called &quot;Views&quot;), and then list all the views, with the ones not available in a given context disabled. Or you could just display the views available in a given context (and use the name for that context) and hide the rest. I don't know what the current thinking is for what is easiest for users.
|Patch Set 5:

I browsed some of the research on this issue, and it seems that while back in 1989 users were still in favour of static menus, they had come to accept and expect dynamic menus by 2004. Not sure what the current research results state. I don't want to spend a lot of time researching this, as we are making the decisions based on personal preferences and feelings.

|Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

The string looks fine.
|Patch Set 1:

I think it's only you ;). Attaching different meanings to a term when it is written as one word and two words is never going to work. If we want to make distinctions between terms that are usually used interchangeably (username, login name, logon name), we have to define them in the dictionary and then use them consistently. Most users will still not get our &quot;special meaning&quot; when encountering a familiar term.
|Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

You could have also replaced these in the docs.
|Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

Hmm, I think I found 14 or so occurrences when I searched, but thanks!
|Patch Set 2:

@hjk: I've worked with some systems that had &quot;usernames&quot; for that purpose and &quot;login names&quot; for the use of the authentication system. The problem is that everyone is free to coin their own therms according to their needs. 

Here is what I found in wikipedia: 

A user is a person who uses a computer or network service. A user often has a user account and is identified by a username (also user name). Other terms for username include login name, screen name (also screenname), nickname (also nick), or handle, which is derived from the identical Citizen's Band radio term.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Username
|Patch Set 2:

Are you thinking about the German grammar, there? In English, compound words can be built in different ways:

&quot;There are three forms of compound words:
the closed form, in which the words are melded together, such as firefly, secondhand, softball, childlike, crosstown, redhead, keyboard, makeup, notebook;
the hyphenated form, such as daughter-in-law, master-at-arms, over-the-counter, six-pack, six-year-old, mass-produced;
and the open form, such as post office, real estate, middle class, full moon, half sister, attorney general.&quot;

http://grammar.ccc.commnet.edu/grammar/compounds.htm

However, I have nothing agains us picking &quot;username&quot; instead of &quot;user name&quot;. We can also fix all &quot;file name&quot; occurrences to &quot;filename&quot; (as we have the same inconsistency in the use of that term).

And, it is useless to try to convince me that one of these is &quot;right&quot; and the other is &quot;wrong&quot;, even though judging by hjk's research, &quot;username&quot; might have become the prominent form.
|Patch Set 2:

@eike: https://www.google.de/search?q=%22user+name%22&amp;tbm=isch&amp;tbo=u&amp;source=univ&amp;sa=X&amp;ei=uYq6U921LKvU4QTEvoDwBQ&amp;ved=0CEkQ7Ak&amp;biw=1920&amp;bih=1068 

Seems to me that Windows has used that form, but I have not seen the latest versions.

|Patch Set 1:

It is fine to use paragraphs in tables. We separate content (.qdoc source files) from formatting (.css), so if there are formatting issues when using the .qdoc codes in supported ways, those should be dealt with in the style sheets. If you start modifying the source code to better fit the current formatting, you might get surprises when the style sheets are changed.

http://doc-snapshot.qt-project.org/qtifw-master/ifw-globalconfig.html
|Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)
|Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

To link to an external resource, you need to add an entry for the link target to qtbase/doc/global/externalsites/external-resources.qdoc and then use that target in this file. 

For example, add the following entry:

/*!
    \externalpage http://rt.openssl.org/Ticket/Display.html?id=3263&amp;user=guest&amp;pass=guest
    \title OpenSSL Bug 3263
*/

Then, link to this as follows: \l {OpenSSL Bug 3263}{bug}

OK, we can keep the MS term for Per-Monitor-Aware. MS seems to use the terms &quot;display&quot; and &quot;monitor&quot; interchangeably in their related documentation:

|Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2
|Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1
|Patch Set 2:

When I was playing around with this, it was really easy to create a non-working theme, where some text elements were the same colour as their background, for example. So, for me, it would be important to group the UI elements, so that I could just select colours for a couple of settings and the UI would still be usable. Maybe we could ask Diana de Sousa, who is designing some additional themes for Qt Creator: http://blog.qt.io/blog/2015/02/09/qt-creator-flat-style-ui-design-new-light-theme/#comment-1194950

Also, the names of the settings should not come from code, but should be in natural language: &quot;Background color&quot;, &quot;Text color&quot;, and so on.
|Patch Set 2: -Code-Review

|Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(21 inline comments)

I have created a new structure for storing qdoc files, and therefore the qtcreator.qdoc file should be moved to doc\src\ and the creator-project-autotools.qdoc file to doc\src\projects.

The creator-project-overivew.qdoc file contains good information, but may be too technical for the Qt Creator Manual, which is about using Qt Creator. This information could go into the Extending Qt Creator Manual, which is written for Qt Creator developers. Please move the file to the doc/api folder.

I added some style comments to make the text read more like the rest of the manual. Also, you should add some qdoc tags, so that the text will be formatted correctly.

|Change has been successfully cherry-picked as 11316763f85e15379185864861bb4aa538368bd2.
|Patch Set 1:

According to the new screenshot guidelines, all screenshots are taken with the resolution 1024x768 and resized to 75% to make them look similar regardless of the display and operating system on which they were taken. 

Please check the content of the screen shots.
|Patch Set 1:

Also, you can open a bug about the graphical guidelines if you feel legibility is more important than a concistent look and feel. There are other ways of doing this (such as allowing the .css to scale the images and allowing readers to click the images to view them in full size), but this is the way chosen, and I cannot suddenly redo all the 300+ screenshots again.

|Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Generally, I think these read better than the old terms. I googled the terminology, and others seem to mix and match 'Watch windows' and 'watching expressions' and 'evaluating expressions' as well:

&quot;If you enter an expression that has a side effect into the Watch window, the side effect will occur every time the expression is evaluated by the Watch window.&quot; (http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/0taedcee.aspx)

So, let's just try to use the new term consistently.
|Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Found a capitalization issue
|Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, approved

|Patch Set 2: (14 inline comments)

This text is mostly grammatically correct, but please consider the following style issues that make it more direct and clear:

- Use active voice
- Use present tense
- Use 'such as' instead of 'like' 
- For selecting menu items or specifying options, start with what the user can do and then give the full path to the item or option: To do x, select y &gt; z &gt; w.

For the docs to be built, you also need to add the following line to activeqt.pro:

QMAKE_DOCS = $$PWD/doc/activeqt.qdocconf

|Patch Set 1:

Did you optimize the images? See here for instructions:

|Patch Set 2:

To make the images consistent with the existing screen shots, please follow these guidelines: 

- User screen resolution 1024x768
- Remove whitespace and shadows around images
- Resize images to 75 %

The doc team is in the process of writing down these guidelines on a wiki and using them for all images in all Qt docs.

|Patch Set 1:

If it is a trademark, we should capitalize it exactly as it says in the trademark. If you mean product name, however, we should decide what the product name is and then capitalized consistently. As an abbreviation of Qt Build Suite, it should actually be QBS, but Andre did not like that when I first created the document.
|Patch Set 1:

Well, the last time we discussed this, we chose Qbs. I don't mind changing it, but it needs to change everywhere and be used consistently. Changing it every time the developers change won't work. Also, all lower case names present a problem in documentation in that they look wrong in titles and in the beginning of sentences. This results in all kinds of workarounds while writing. Also, other tools seem to have begun to use more standard capitalization. For example CMake, Git, and so on.
|Patch Set 1:

No, I mean in the beginning of times, when I set up the Qbs Manual, and hjk made me change all references to QBS to Qbs.
|Patch Set 1:

I would go with QBS for &quot;Qt Build Suite&quot; or Qbs, when it is not a part of a command that you need to type verbatim. Only in the latter case would I use qbs.
|Patch Set 1:

And I think I've seen it written as QBS somewhere, but I don't remember where.

|Patch Set 11: (10 inline comments)

We are getting there, but you still need to fix some values of qdoc commands to fix some links. The values of the \nextpage and \previouspage must be filenames or titles of existing HTML pages. The \page command determines the filename of a page.

Also, fix the way some product names are written and please consider the style issues I point out in the inline comments.
|Patch Set 11:

One more thing, please check that the lines in all files are maximum 80 characters long (except for URLs in links (\l), which sometimes have to be longer as they must be placed all on one line).

(2 inline comments)

You need to use the standard punctuation for the tooltips. 

As to whether your should observe the string freeze, the main argument for that (in my mind) is making it possible for the translators to do their task well. It is really frustrating to spend a lot of time and effort on something only to have someone else's actions make the end result less than perfect. And having any English-language strings in the UI is less than perfect.
|Patch Set 2:

@Robert: yes, engineers always want to improve everything until the last minute, and that is exactly why we have screen freezes and deadlines and master for polishing and fixing minor issues.

|Patch Set 1:

I would not do this, as &quot;qbs-&quot; is actually a pretty short prefix and there are some vague ideas about putting all the HTML files back to one doc directory to solve some issues with locating them and redirecting links.
|Patch Set 1:

What I meant by that is that it is possible that the folder structure will change again in the future, because the current structure causes problems when finding the latest documentation or redirecting to it. But nothing has been decided yet or is in definite plans.

The front page for each Qt 5 module is called &lt;qtmodule&gt;-index.html to avoid conflicts. The Qbs manual front page should actually be renamed qbs-index.html to be consistent with this naming style.

Not using contractions in UI text is a rule in Qt Creator context, and it would be good to observe the same rules for all tools (and for Qt itself): http://doc-snapshot.qt-project.org/qtcreator-extending/qtcreator-ui-text.html. I also  observe this rule in all the documentation I write and edit. I marked some other issues that could be fixed as part of this commit or a separate commit.
|Patch Set 3:

Let's try again, this time without punctuation: http://doc-snapshot.qt-project.org/qtcreator-extending/qtcreator-ui-text.html

|Patch Set 9: (1 inline comment)


|Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, approved

Thanks! 

As to the remaining errors:

qtwinextras/src/winextras/doc/src/qtwinextras-module-cpp.qdoc:35: warning: Unknown command '\qtvariable'

This qdoc command will be introduced in Qt 5.2 (dev), so it should not appear when you build the docs with a recent Qt from dev (maybe from the root level, that is, qt5 directory)

qtwinextras/src/winextras/doc/src/qtwinextras-examples.qdoc:28: warning: Can't link to 'Qt for Windows'

This link points to the qtdoc module, so the error should not appear after Qt Windows Extras becomes part of Qt 5.2 and you build the docs from the root level.

|Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)


|Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

The lists are generated when built with Qt 5.1, but they are not generated when built with Qt 4.8, so this effectively breaks doc generation with QDoc3 (Qt 4.x).  Also, any items not listed in the list on the index.html page will not be displayed in the Contents list in Qt Creator.
|Patch Set 3:

1) Do we really need to support Qt 4?
2) You could just provide the content and I could take care of the structure, like we do for the Qt Creator Manual.
|Patch Set 3:

Yes, I'm suggesting that we drop all support for building documentation with Qt 4, the same way we are going with Qt Creator 3.

But please create bugs or suggestions in JIRA for anything that would make your life easier. Qdoc bugs and suggestions can be assigned to Martin Smith and HTML template bugs and suggestions to Jerome Pasion.

|Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)


|Patch Set 3:

To me, there is no clear difference between &quot;hidden&quot; and &quot;non-visible&quot; in meaning, except that &quot;hidden&quot; might indicate intent. Here, I suppose the non-visible editors are hidden on purpose, so I don't see a problem there. However, &quot;non-visible&quot; is somewhat awkward as a term, because how do you capitalize it, for example, and that is why I prefer &quot;hidden&quot;.  

Both terms would work better with the term &quot;Editors&quot; added, but that would mean checking consistency with all the existing menu items (that is, would &quot;editors&quot; have to be added to them, too). Also, I don't think the difference between &quot;Close Others&quot; and &quot;Close Non-Visible&quot; (or should it be &quot;Close Non-visible&quot;) or &quot;Close Hidden&quot; will be clear. Maybe &quot;Close Others&quot; should now become &quot;Close All Except Current&quot;, which would then actually fit well with the original suggestion for the new item.
|Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve


|Patch Set 4:

The translatable string seems to be gone from patch set 4. I agree with Eike on that we should try to preserve consistency, so &quot;Search in Containing Folder&quot; would be OK in that context.
|Patch Set 4:

I would prefer using &quot;Find in This Directory&quot; (or &quot;Find in This Folder&quot;) everywhere, for consistency. I think &quot;this&quot; is actually clearer than &quot;containing&quot;, as a file is always located in a folder. And we need to choose either &quot;folder&quot; or &quot;directory&quot; and use it everywhere in the UI and docs.
|Patch Set 5:

The ellipsis is used to indicate that further action is required by the user before the action is actually applied: &quot;Place three full stops (...) at the end of menu item names that open a dialog requiring user action.&quot;

You can find the guidelines for creating UI text here: http://doc-snapshot.qt-project.org/qtcreator-extending/qtcreator-ui-text.html

Not everything is correct, yet, but I'm fixing things when I run into them.

|Patch Set 2:

Sorry, I was not being clear. There are two correct ways to do this:

1) If this is a title: &quot;Select Native SDK Path&quot;

2) If this is a label: &quot;Select Native SDK path:&quot;

The differences are in capitalization and in whether you should place a colon in the end.  Unfortunately, the current version would be wrong in both cases.

|Change has been successfully cherry-picked as a5375cbe32ce7fcfd7d5cf85803a1d812641dc31.
|Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(20 inline comments)

These are incomplete sentences with an ellipsis in the beginning. The form of the verb depends on the part of the sentence that has been omitted.

To test whether the verb could be in third person singular form, try adding &quot;This option&quot; to the beginning of the tooltip in your mind. If the tooltip is still grammatically correct, you can add the &quot;s&quot;.

However, if you would need to add &quot;Select this option to&quot;, for the resulting tooltip to be grammatically correct, the verb should be in first person singular form (without the &quot;s&quot;).
|Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, approved

OK, you convinced me ;). Let's try to keep this consistent to make things easier for translators. I think there might still be some inconsistency in the existing tooltips, though.

|Patch Set 2:

You forgot to add the flashing argument needed for Dual. I just added this:

    To deploy the image on i.MX6Quad, enter the following commands:

    \badcode
        cd &lt;INSTALL_DIR&gt;
        sudo Boot2Qt-4.x/imx6qsabresd-eLinux/images/deploy.sh /dev/&lt;device_name&gt;
    \endcode

    To deploy the image on i.MX6Dual, you need to enter an additional boot
    argument:

    \badcode
        cd &lt;INSTALL_DIR&gt;
        sudo Boot2Qt-4.x/imx6qsabresd-eLinux/images/deploy.sh --uboot u-boot-imx6dlsabresd.imx /dev/&lt;device_name&gt;
    \endcode

|Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1
|Patch Set 5:

Definition of &quot;context&quot;:

&quot;the interrelated conditions in which something exists or occurs :  environment, setting &lt;the historical context of the war&gt;&quot; 

http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/context

So, I think it is more correct to say that &quot;x is the context for y&quot; that to speak about a &quot;context appearing&quot;.

|Patch Set 15:

(7 comments)
|Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1
|Patch Set 1:

In principle, we are of course free to  guidelines for taking Qt Creator screenshots to replace the current ones here: http://doc-snapshots.qt.io/qtcreator-extending/qtcreator-documentation.html

But I really don't see how we could manage to agree on the new guidelines and take the new screenshots in time for the 4.0 release that is planned for May 3: http://wiki.qt.io/Qt_Creator_Releases

I created a task for updating the rules. You can vote for it and add your opinions and ideas there: https://bugreports.qt.io/browse/QTCREATORBUG-16076

Taking 300+ screenshots is a lot of work and takes a lot of time. It would be great to have some kind of semi-automatic system for taking the screenshots by using Squish.

I created a task for that here: https://bugreports.qt.io/browse/QTCREATORBUG-16077

Please continue the discussion about the guidelines and improving the work flow in those tasks.
|Patch Set 1:

Tim, did you find any problems with the contents of the screenshots?

I also like the new theme, but I think hjk's comment about naming the themes is valid. The names should be as descriptive as possible and easy to extend:

- Manhattan (the old style)
- Flat (is this dark or light, will matter when a second option comes along)
- FlatDark
- FlatLight
- FlatPinkUnicorns
- FlatDark2015
- FlatLight2015
- FlatDark2016 (or whenever the next flat dark style comes along)
...

This attempts to answer the question why there is no table mapping QSslError values and QWebEngineCertificate values. The reported of QTBUG-53332 wrote: &quot;A table depicting the mapping between QSslError values and QWebEngineCertificateError values is missing inside the documentation (and/or porting guide).&quot; 

I think mentioning the Chromium errors first might sound less abrupt, so I switched the order.

|Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(30 comments)

- The link to this page is currently broken, because the value of the \l command do not match.
- This topic should have a \title command with the page title, and all \section2 commands should be \section1
- If you can, use book style capitalization for the title. Not sure what your options are, because you are automatically generating the page
- QDoc reads the &quot;*/&quot; string as a command to end the topic, so you'll need to remove all but the last one, unless QDoc is fixed to ignore the string within the \code command
- Something else breaks the page generation in the &quot;libsecret&quot; section, but I cannot see what
|Patch Set 3:

(12 comments)

I really like the table format!

The &quot;Project Homepage&quot; links are also useful, but I suppose these external links will not work in the qch file. To make them work, you would have to add them to qtwebengine\src\webengine\doc\src\external-resources.qdoc or generate a separate 3rdparty-links.qdoc (it can be called anything, I think) for them.

Some of the &quot;Project Homepage&quot; links are broken in different ways. Maybe you could add a disclaimer that they are derived from the files and we do not check them.
|Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

When you have the time, please think about ways to pull the Project Homepage links into qtwebengine\src\webengine\doc\src\external-resources.qdoc or generate a separate 3rdparty-links.qdoc (it can be called anything, I think) with \externalpage entries for each homepage. You'd need to use unique titles, though:

/*!
    \externalpage http://zlib.net/
    \title zlib Project Homepage
*/
|Patch Set 4:

I just checked on Qt Creator 4.0.0 and the external links actually work. Topi, why are we still using the \externalpage mechanism?

|Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(31 comments)

I found a typo. Also, docs are missing. QML properties are not usually documented as returning something, I think.

http://doc-snapshots.qt.io/qt5-dev/13-qdoc-commands-topics.html#qmlproperty-command

Please run &quot;make docs&quot; (or nmake docs on Windows) and check the warnings and HTML output when you add docs. QDoc will help you find a lot of errors. For more information, see:

https://wiki.qt.io/Building_Qt_Documentation
|Patch Set 8:

Also, the docs for all the properties of this class are missing from the C++ class doc. You must document them in the .cpp file using the \property or \enum command, depending on their type:

http://doc-snapshots.qt.io/qt5-dev/13-qdoc-commands-topics.html#property-command

http://doc-snapshots.qt.io/qt5-dev/13-qdoc-commands-topics.html#enum-command
|Patch Set 9: Code-Review+1

There seem to be some default docs generated for the constructor (or maybe they are somewhere else in the file), but I think that can be fixed in a later commit for 5.7. Also, the property docs can be added later for 5.7.

|Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(7 comments)

The _lgpl files are used for docs that were copied from Qt WebKit. New C++ docs should be placed in the respective .cpp file. These should go to qwebenginepage.cpp and qwebengineview.cpp.

QDoc can only find the documented functions if the signature is identical to the declaration, including const qualifiers. You can find out what QDoc is looking for by checking the doc build warnings or looking at the headings generated by QDoc in the HTML docs.
|Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)

|Patch Set 11: Code-Review+1
|Patch Set 14: Code-Review-1

(8 comments)

When you change the code, you should also check that the documentation still applies. Please run QDoc to get warnings and errors for missing documentation.

|Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

When linking to methods (using \l or \sa or just the method name for an automatic link), add empy braces to the end. If several function variants are documented, you also add the arguments to tell QDoc which variant you want.

|Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2
|Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(56 comments)

Looks good, but some grammar fixes are needed.
|Patch Set 6:

(37 comments)

Usually, when you start a sentence with a clause that starts with &quot;in&quot;, &quot;when&quot;, &quot;whenever&quot; or &quot;after&quot;, you will need to add a comma at the end of the clause.

In Qt docs, we use &quot;that&quot; without a comma for restrictive clauses and &quot;which&quot; with a comma for non-restrictive clauses.
|Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1
|Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)
|Patch Set 8: Code-Review+1
|Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)

I agree with Ulf's other comments, but I would use the plural form of &quot;players&quot;, to avoid having to write &quot;he or she&quot; (or similar) or to use the singular &quot;they&quot;, which many readers still consider wrong.

|Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)
|Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

How about:

- Add \brief commands for each \class. These could use a standard format: &quot;The xxx class is used by compiled state machines.&quot;

- Add a short description about what each class does, and then a standard text about how they are only used internally by the state machines and the note about BC.

- Add basic documentation for properties, functions, etc.

|If dx/dy are long enough, we create above 2 additional mouseMove event.

So instead of going from x to x+dx, the cursor moves from x to x+1/3dx, then to x+2/3dx and then to dx (idem for y)

The idea here is to create intermediate mouse events, more than one when possible. Does it make sense now?

@Venu: To test, you need to check out the patch so it also pull the changes it depends on. Then you can build Quick Forecast with Qt 5.2.1 or Qt 5.3.0 for Android (or other). |Uploaded patch set 4.
|Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

@Liang: uiLanguages is probably more appropriate to use than system.name indeed. But the on Mac/iOS, the uiLanguage for Chinese Simplified and Traditional are sz-Hans and sz-Hant while the system name is sz_CN or for example sz_SG. On iOS the system name change while changing the region, on Mac, it changes with the language,Qlocale.system does not change with the region but only with the language. I don't see a consistent behaviour here. Well, for now I will keep using the system name and I will have to figure out later if I should change to uiLanguages and thus how to handle the language names syntax issues - vs _

|Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2
|Patch Set 18: I would prefer this is not merged as is

Here are some findings for now.

I have tried on Ubuntu and Android. I encounter some issues when the handles are very close to one another. It becomes difficult to know which handle will be grabbed and how the selection with then behaves.

On Android, the selction is not clear when the control lost active focus (switching from the TF to TA and vice versa). It should probably be cleared.

On Android, press and hold a work select it. When selected, it seems impossible to drag the right handle. When doing so the handle &quot;jumps&quot; to the left handle. Moving the left handle is fine.

|Patch Set 5:

With the current design, it does not look good on Windows phone.

Depending on some items geometries compared to the size available, the app decreases the size of items in the zoom page, or removes some items in the long term page.

For info, QTBUG-39154 in layout prevents currently to use an invisible layout to gets its implicit size so we can't use it.

I have tested this change and iOS/Android/Mac/Linux. On desktop the app can be resized manually and in some cases the design is adjusted after navigating back and forth to reload the page. Compared to what we currently have, I don't think that's a problem. What do you think?

@Andrew, how does it look like now on WinRT?
|Patch Set 5:

@Andrew: could you try this change on a Windows phone when you have the time?
|Patch Set 5:

I have tested the change on Ubuntu with w/h 480/800 (isMobile = false) and it looked ok for me...

|Uploaded patch set 5.
|Patch Set 5: -Code-Review

I have this fix for the events/break problem. It seems to fix the break data not displaying and the crash on iOS when switching conferences.

When some fields in the database are empty, it leads to the role index being different between the two conferences. And it seems that once a role index has been set, the view does not forget about it. In some case it hits another existing role number and displays whatever it contains (or nothing if empty) or it leads to crashes when the role does not exist. I try resseting the model but with no success.

What do you think?

diff --git a/tests/auto/controls/data/tst_tableview.qml b/tests/auto/controls/da
index 71f92a3..360b1f7 100644
--- a/tests/auto/controls/data/tst_tableview.qml
+++ b/tests/auto/controls/data/tst_tableview.qml
@@ -516,7 +516,7 @@ TestCase {
         table.forceActiveFocus();
 
         // to go to next row (this model has 10 rows)
-        table.__incrementCurrentIndex()
+        table.__mouseArea.__incrementCurrentIndex()
 
         // read data from the model directly
         var valuefrommodel = table.model.dataAt(table.currentRow)
@@ -545,7 +545,7 @@ TestCase {
         table.forceActiveFocus();
 
         // to go to next row (this model has 3 rows, read the second row)
-        table.__incrementCurrentIndex()
+        table.__mouseArea.__incrementCurrentIndex()
 
         verify(table.__currentRowItem !== undefined, &quot;No current item found&quot;)

Thanks for the tip Topi. You were right [QtQuickControlsStyles] had no effect, I removed it.

Also, we used a lot of references to {QtQuick.Controls.Styles::}, and while those are correct, they are not needed. I think we should keep references to other modules when it is absolutely needed to keep the doc lighter and make the needed cross module references more obvious. Hope you agree :)

qt5 should not be smart I suppose.

I seems to me that 10.10 is the platform to blacklist for most of the cases now. I can't be 100% sure I didn't forget to blacklist a flaky test on a given platform but I think this will bring value to the tests anyway.

|Patch Set 1:

For shadow builds, the BLACKLIST file that is found in the pro file folder may not be found.

See for example http://testresults.qt.io/ci/QtBase_5.5_Integration/build_00785/linux-g++_shadow-build_Ubuntu_14.04_x64/log.txt.gz
FAIL!  : tst_QGraphicsProxyWidget::hoverEnterLeaveEvent(widget, no hover) is failing while hoverEnterLeaveEvent is blacklisted for 14.04. It is because the test tried to find the BLACKLIST file using QString filename = QTest::qFindTestData(QStringLiteral(&quot;BLACKLIST&quot;)); but in case of shadow build, it will never look into the source folder.

I though it could be a solution to copy the BLACKLIST file to the $$OUT_PWD folder- What do you think?

|Patch Set 13:

The __FILE__ path is indeed not always absolute, it can be relative (to the build output). I think that as long as QT_TESTCASE_BUILDDIR is defined, the return mainSourcePath returned should be correct. I didn't check for QT_TESTCASE_BUILDDIR at first and did not always get the correct path.
|Patch Set 13:

Ok, I tried using QDir::currentPath() instead of the build directory.

In the case of testlib selftest, when executing a subtest, the currentPath is &quot;/home/caroline/git/55/qtbase/tests/auto/testlib/shadow&quot;

So the blacklist file cannot be found. The default behaviour resolve the blacklist past using the working directory too, which means it looks into &quot;/home/caroline/git/55/qtbase/tests/auto/selftests/blacklisted&quot; instead of &quot;/home/caroline/git/55/qtbase/tests/auto/testlib/shadow/blacklisted&quot;

|Uploaded patch set 7.
|Patch Set 7:

The test on Red Hat have been failing 57 times for the last 200 builds I have checked (those 200 builds may include aborted builds). So it is not all the time but quite often.

Regarding the blacklisting topic, I do agree that investigating and fixing the code/tests are best. And also while I update/create a bug report for each test I move to a blacklist file, tests can stay blacklisted forever if no one investigate the problems.

However as long as a test is marked as insignificant, real regressions can be introduced without being noticed (for example tst_QDBusMarshall::sendSignalErrors() failure observed during the merge: https://codereview.qt-project.org/#/c/109467/).

The QUdpSocket test is insignificant on all platforms at the moment. While I am not familiar with this code, by using blacklist instead of insignificant_tests for this test, it can help make lots of tests significant again (more than 70 for that test).

This is what I am focusing on at the moment, for this test and other tests/modules as well. Making sure that blacklisted are not forgotten is of course an important state. But if fixing a test is not straighforward, having an intermediate blacklisted state for the CI is not a problem and even help identifying which specific tests are failing.

Add missing comments:

&gt; ok. thanks for your comments.

&gt; I am not 100% it would break but better prevent than treat afterwards (French expression) :))

&gt; 
&gt; A change even more minimal would be to revert the changes with $(CXX) and even put back the silent: condition line. Create resolve_compilers.prf as you suggested but that contains only something like:

run into that double prefix problem, indeed (i entirely forgot about it;

QMAKE_CXX&quot;) to the three affected project files - not as clean, but i

|Patch Set 3:

I agree with Jing. It would nice to have the option to enable it instead of forcing it. i.e. qmake --add-major-version.

Also instead of hard-coding the tool name version, it may be more flexible to have moc$$QT_MAJOR_VERSION and something similar in the source code to append the version to each tool's name instead of hard-coding it. The relevant version could be only store in one file and this way it would make changes easier in future versions of qt (qt6!) with only a single file to update.

Also I think it would be nice to have qdoc5 for more consistency even if we now moved qdoc3 to qdoc. So we start qt 5 with a clean state.

|Uploaded patch set 2.
|Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Adding a test case in patch set 2.
|Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

With the change cff4683a, prepared queries can now store a named paramater to be used more than once. When using ?, thus positional binding, there is no name parameter.

When prepare is called from a query with ?, it causes an error when the feature QSqlDriver::NamedPlaceholders is true. Because holders values are called while holders is actually empty.

QSqlDriver::NamedPlaceholders is true for QOCI plugin only but the problem is independant of the plugin used. The added test case is an attempt to make the test runnable without Oracle installed. The qsqlquery only runs tests for the found drivers. Also the problem lies in qsqlresult, that's why I created tst_qsqlresult.

After reflexion, I wonder if instead of having guards before calling holders[count], this should just be removed because it seems useless.

Adding Matt Newell who wrote the initial change cff4683a for comments on this.
|Patch Set 2:

any comment?

Also the sha1 is cff46983a
|Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)


|Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

I changed hasFeature(NamedPlaceholders) to return false instead of true in qsql_oci.cpp.

Then I tried:

    query.prepare(&quot;INSERT INTO MYTABLE (ID, NAME, BIRTH) VALUES(?, ?, ?)&quot;);
    query.addBindValue(1);
    query.addBindValue(&quot;foo1&quot;);
    query.addBindValue(QDate(2012, 11, 29));

    if (!query.exec()) {
        qDebug() &lt;&lt; &quot;insert with ? failed&quot; &lt;&lt; query.lastError().text();
        return 3;
    }

And I got the message error:

    Error: insert with ? failed &quot;ORA-009 Unable to execute statement

So I wouldn't change that value :)

|Patch Set 1:

Built on Windows 7 with mingw, and run sql tests successfully.
|Patch Set 1:

It is currently necessary to add QT+=sql-private in order to do for example:

#include &lt;QtCore&gt;
#include &lt;QtSql/QSqlDatabase&gt;
#include &lt;QtSql/QOCIDriver&gt;
#include &lt;QDebug&gt;

int main(int /*argc*/, char * /*argv[]*/) {
    QSqlDatabase::registerSqlDriver(&quot;QOCI&quot;, new QSqlDriverCreator&lt;QOCIDriver&gt;);
    qDebug() &lt;&lt; QSqlDatabase::drivers();
    return 0;
}

Because QOCIDriver (for example here) includes the private header. See bug report:
https://bugreports.qt-project.org/browse/QTBUG-28088

The Sql drivers can be built as plugin but also be built inside the Qt library using the configure option -qt-sql-&lt;driver&gt;.

see https://codereview.qt-project.org/#change,46405

|Patch Set 1:

The problem is the signal activated() won't be emitted when there is an itemdelegate set (I missed that in Iff3e5c1c)

What about keeping mouse.accepted = false but calling root.activated in onPressed instead? Like:

if (listView.currentIndex !== -1)
   root.activated()


And adding the new test:


    function test_activatedWithDelegate() {

        var component = 
Qt.createComponent(&quot;tableview/table_delegate.qml&quot;)

        compare(component.status, Component.Ready)

        var table =  component.createObject(container);

        verify(table !== null, &quot;table created is null&quot;)

        table.forceActiveFocus();

        compare(table.test_activated, false)

        mouseDoubleClick(table, 15 , 55, Qt.LeftButton)

        compare(table.test_activated, true)

        table.destroy()
    }

With the change in table_delegate.qml:

diff --git 

a/tests/auto/controls/data/tableview/table_delegate.qml 

b/tests/auto/controls/data/tableview/table_delegate.qml

index 38f4c1c..b50d05c 100644

--- a/tests/auto/controls/data/tableview/table_delegate.qml

+++ b/tests/auto/controls/data/tableview/table_delegate.qml

@@ -46,6 +46,9 @@ TableView {
     model: [{&quot;text&quot;: &quot;text1&quot;}, {&quot;text&quot;: &quot;text2&quot;}, {&quot;text&quot;: &quot;text3&quot;}]

     property var test: 0
 

+    property bool test_activated: false

+    onActivated: test_activated = true

+

     TableViewColumn {

         title: &quot;Text&quot;

         role: &quot;text&quot;

|Patch Set 1: Do not submit

Kai, now that we have pro files for each example, I was thinking making this change.

After talking with Iikka I think this will not work though.

It seems that during the package creation &quot;make install&quot; is not called for the examples but instead the examples sources are copied directly in the package, what's called &quot;injection&quot;.

So it is not possible to move up the qt quick controls examples for the package sake, right?

|Patch Set 3:

|Uploaded patch set 4.
|Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)


|Patch Set 4:

&quot;Why do you not want a private plugin? That is the correct solution, and this solution does not make the private plugin APIs any more restricted.&quot;


Removing the private plugin simplifies the solution to embed the qml/js file in a resource file. See:
https://codereview.qt-project.org/#change,61975

The plugin would then contain all the c++ api and it would be easier to embed all the qml/js files in it. Those files would be loaded if they are not found locally (actually if ApplicationWindow.qml is missing, the files are loaded from the qrc). From a deployment point of view, only 1 plugin and 1 qmldir would be needed.

If we have the private plugin, we may need to keep those 2 plugins or to duplicate the c++ api of the private plugin inside the non-private one and also have another qmldir. And if we keep the 2 plugins and want to embed the files in resource, I haven't found a nice solution to deal with the Base style; some files are used in the Private module, some in the Style module and some other are common and should be available for all files.
|Patch Set 4:

Anyone else with comments? Do you think like Alan that having 2 plugins with local import instead of module import may be a better solution than the one presented here?
|Patch Set 4: Abandoned

moved to dev:
https://codereview.qt-project.org/#change,62759

if we remove &quot;controls&quot; from the the example dir in the qdocconf file and use &quot;controls/examplename&quot; instead, a file called controls-examplename.html is generated. to investigate.

|Patch Set 3:

Here is another version using 2 plugins (4 files). I am using the plugin.cpp of the controls and private modules. Also instead of registering the qml files in the plugin.cpp, I do it in the qmldir files so the changes to the cpp files are minimal.

The QtQuick.Controls.Styles module is available via the QtQuick.Controls plugin.

Private API are only available when importing QtQuick.Controls.Private (unlike https://codereview.qt-project.org/#change,59065 - single plugin)
|Uploaded patch set 4.
|Patch Set 3: (3 inline comments)

This solution and the solution in https://codereview.qt-project.org/#change,59344 require a cleaning of QtQuick.Controls ONLY and qmake QT_CONFIG+=deploy / make.
(Qt Quick Layout is a separate module.)

As Friedemann said &quot;Works in principle but...&quot;

Let me gather here concerns that remain:

- With those solutions the users need the sources.

- Then, having to remove the current installation is probably not a good solution. But then deploying to something like QtQuick/Controls/Deploy does not sound too good either.

- One way could be to make those available in a file to download somewhere. That's something else to take care of.

- The deployment qrc/qmldir files need to be maintained and prone to errors. and need to be tested too.

I can't see a solution that really convinces me at the moment. (for memo, gathering the currently installed files inside a single plugin does not work because the dll cannot be loaded when embedded in a resource file)

But now there are two questions: what can we offer to users in the short term (from 5.1.1) and what can we change in 5.2 in Qt Quick to solve this problem in a general way for Qt Quick Controls and other Qt Quick based projects.
|Patch Set 4: Abandoned

see https://codereview.qt-project.org/#change,62760
|Uploaded patch set 2.
|Uploaded patch set 3.
|Uploaded patch set 4.
|Uploaded patch set 5.
|Patch Set 5: Do not submit

WIP
|Uploaded patch set 6.
|Patch Set 6: No score

No nice to maintain, but I can't think of another solution at the moment.

The idea is the user will run qmake QT_CONFIG+=deploy and only 2 files (1 dll and 1 qmldir file) will be deployed under QtQuick.Controls and could be used while deploying their app.
|Patch Set 6:

I should also add that with this solution, all c++ API is available when you include QtQuick.Controls to the project, i.e. the c++ private API are also register as part of QtQuick.Controls (instead of QtQuick.Controls.Private without the 'deploy' configure option.)

While the structure is slightly different from the original one, this allows the controls to be deployed as a single plugin. As long as it is only used for deployment I think this is fine but we can discuss it. A solution using 3 dll/qmldir is still possible.
|Patch Set 6:

I need to register the qml files because there is no qmldir file in the qrc file for the controls. And if I add one it does not work, because the module name has to be QtQuick.Controls which conflicts with the original one, i.e. the one in qtbase/qml/QtQuick/Controls loading the plugin.

For info, I have also tried something else as suggested by JP: embedding all the qml/js/and dlls files from qml/QtQuick/Controls inside a plugin (and respecting the tree structure) but it does not work. The dll cannot be opened when they are inside a qrc file.
|Patch Set 6: (2 inline comments)

the qml files need to be registered, via the qmlextensionplugin or via a qmldir. The qmldir conflict is when you have 2 qmldir files for the same module (one in the qml tree and one in the qrc file in this case)

But since then, I have actually found out that I could add in the &quot;not in qrc&quot; qmldir file, a path to the qml files inside the resources using the full path, i.e. 

Button 1.0 qrc:/Deploy/QtQuick/Controls/Button.qml

|Patch Set 3:

The ios problem has been fixed so updating to initial change.

Also we need the following bugs (or at least one of them) fixed before pushing this change:
https://bugreports.qt-project.org/browse/QTBUG-34342
https://bugreports.qt-project.org/browse/QTBUG-34343

Otherwise it fails on Windows builds where the config release_and_debug is used but only release is built. On Windows empty Private and Style folders are created in the target directory when running qmake and the release plugin try to load qml files from there, thus it creates a failure.
|Patch Set 3:

Fawzi Mohamed		12:25 PM

I am thorn about this change. From one side yes the files are not needed in the application, but it makes toolability worse (no debugging, worse code model), and I wonder if release build == Not used for development. I guess worse tooling is expected in a release build, but I wonder if this is the right trade off
	
Shawn Rutledge		12:34 PM

Yes it's the right tradeoff, because it makes no sense to bundle QML files twice into every Android app when the user can't access them either way. And developers can use debug builds.

Fawzi Mohamed		12:40 PM

I fully agree that it makes no sense to ship them in the application, but I wonder if the &quot;don't ship&quot; should not be done in another place (in the deploy step of the application)
|Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

Under discussion


The windows deployment tool does not deploy the .qml/.js file. That's a good approach too.

But it also means that each tool would need to know the modules that have files in both resources and the directory. Currently only Controls and Dialogs module have this structure (I think).

|Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Tony do you know?

Putting -1 for now just to be sure everyone agree before it could go in :) I am not familiar with QtWayland but I think this can be cleaned up a bit.

For info in 5.4 and 5.4.1 integration, the only stage I find is:
&quot;linux-g++_developer-build_OpenSuSE_13.1_x64&quot;
|Patch Set 1:

Hmm, I am a bit confused. I would think that https://codereview.qt-project.org/92042  is correct. Because QtWayland is not a module used on all platforms.

I am not sure why non relevant platforms have been added in CI. We can let a module &quot;decide&quot; that it will be built or not on a platform, but in the case it does nothing, it &quot;wastes&quot; a checkout/configure... It does not feel optimal. But maybe I am wrong, I don't have much experience with the CI.

Are the platform builds added to stages automatically?
|Patch Set 1:

Ok, so it seems that it should be up to the module to decide, because for example when the whole Qt 5 is built, if QtWayland is not properly configured in its pro file to do nothing for such platforms, then it can break the whole build. Isn't Tony?

One thing though, is why they have force success set? Won't it hide problems?

Well I guess, I will abandon this change then. Or anyone with other comments?

|Patch Set 4:

With https://codereview.qt-project.org/#/c/110509/ and this change, we wanted to mimic the behavior of /usr/bin/lsb_release script by checking also /etc/redhat-release and /etc/debian_version.

By adding moving the piece of common code static QByteArray getEtcFileFirstLine(const char *fileName) into the other change, it appears, what's left for this change did not seem to justify a new patch set.

Also by squashing the patches, the commit message explains fully and in one place the expectations behind the change.

|Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2

WIP: Looking at Qt::KeyboardModifiers QKeyEvent::modifiers() in /home/caroline/git/5.4/qtbase/src/gui/kernel/qevent.cpp, modifier are added when a &quot;key&quot; matching a modifier is added.

When checking the key events (for example using a QWindow or in a QML Item) when shift is released, the matching modifier is cleaned. Which is not the case currently using QTest::keyEvent. This seems to fix the problem. However I am not familiar with this code so wonder what you think about this change.

I should probably add an autotest (not sure where yet :))
|Patch Set 2:

Thanks Friedermann!

With the current implementation, QWindowSystemInterface::handleKeyEvent returns:
- on Press, key Shift and no modifier: modifier ShiftModifier
- on Release, key Shift and no modifier: modifier NoModifier

While on physical Shift press/release:
- on Press, key Shift: modifier ShiftModifier
- on Release, key Shift: modifier ShiftModifier

releasePressEvent is inconsistent between those calls.

Width the patch you suggested, the release event modifer would be 0 as you expect when Shift is physically released but the release event modifier generated would be ShiftModifier.

I wonder if when sending a Shift key, the Shift modifier should always be set maybe?

I have tested using:
http://cutebin.fi/p6dsher6l

I am not really sure what's the correct behaviour.

|Patch Set 2:

This works for me when building and installing the docs:

- make docs
- make install_docs (which copy the doc over to the compiler doc dir)

Antti, in the installed package the qch file for the VKB is under EnterpriseAddOns/QtVirtualKeyboard/1.0/Src/doc. But the doc is not under the gcc_64 (linux) folder.
How to you build the doc for the VKB?

Also when doing make install_docs, the doc doesn't need to be registered in Qt Creator, at startup it picks up the doc automatically it seems.

Also if the examples-manifest.xml is not in the QT_INSTALL_DOCS path, it cannot be seen by Qt Creator. So make install_docs seems to be needed for seeing the examples in Creator.

|Patch Set 15:

- Add comments in pr* files

- Add missing support for saving execution report of plugins. Plugins execution data will be saved within the execution report (csexe) of the application loading them.

Warning: the code database (csmes) of the application (test) does not contain the code of the plugins. Merging the test csmes with the plugins csmes is needed to generate a coverage analysis of the plugins code.

|Change has been successfully cherry-picked to the staging branch as 4306275f64e938ed74451a359a55f1c76af3253f.
|Uploaded patch set 2.
|Patch Set 1:

This is interesting...

Here is the ploblem I tried to solve here. In this case dummyplugin.h contains both functions declarations and functions definitions. So dummyplugin.h is subject to instrumentation.

When the dummyplugin project is built, both dummyplugin.cpp and dummyplugin.h are instrumented because dummyplugin.h is in the current directory. As said above, dummyplugin.h instrumentation is not empty because it contains functions definitions. 

If another project (e.g. dummyplugimemory) uses dummyplugin.h and dummyplugin.cpp, it will include the instrumentation for dummyplugin.cpp (ie source file) but will not instrument the code in dummyplugin.h (ie header file) because it is not in the same folder. The reason is to avoid instrumenting templates and inline functions of 3rd party library.

Thus the instrumentation of dummyplugin.cpp is not consistent between dummyplugin and dummypluginmemory project and their instrumentation databases are incompatible and cannot be merged.

BUT your point about e.g. qatomic_windows.h makes me realise that some headers files of the Qt modules are never instrumented because their are not part of a project folder. It is silent in this case because no file uses them for their own instrumentation since no one includes them for their instrumentation. But qatomic_windows should be instrumented as I see it has inline functions. I am not sure how to solve this at this point. Thus identifying all those headers per folder and include them in a nice way. The headers are copied to $$QT_MODULE_INCLUDE_BASE so we may include this folder but this may lead to some header files being instrumented twice if they are also instrumented as part as a project (like qdbusabstractadaptor.h). I need to check, I don't know a solution yet.

Thanks for raising this issue.
|Patch Set 1:

Jira task: https://bugreports.qt.nokia.com/browse/QTQAINFRA-345

|Patch Set 1:

__coveragescanner_register_library calls dlopen. Not calling__coveragescanner_unregister_library (dlclose) means the library will stay loaded and coverage data can be collected until the application exits.

|Change has been successfully cherry-picked to the staging branch as bd205066a70689195c8eb21ff1dfbe2c26e05c03.
|Change has been successfully cherry-picked to the staging branch as c43a29767bcf9b562737c81ee669b5888ec93a63.
|Change has been successfully cherry-picked to the staging branch as 19d28aea3c3f5d25a25a77a92e9b9825b7926e32.
|Change has been successfully cherry-picked to the staging branch as da8cfc337594649c4c2eab72ea34c41175255407.
|Change has been successfully cherry-picked to the staging branch as 39d31f534bbb0d497f118e61c03aa2d4f92ff0c5.
|Change has been successfully cherry-picked to the staging branch as 9df2da5b9feab42d93548db701fc7f649fd362ab.
|Patch Set 1:

This will not decrease the coverage.

Coverage data is saved every time __coveragescanner_save() is called. In which execution report (csexe) depends on the last application/library who called _coveragescanner_install.

Each binary that is built with test cocoon will generate execution data for the code that has been executed by the application. In the case of application.exe, the data can be saved in application.csexe or plugin.csexe if the plugin was loaded by application.exe and if this application has called __coveragescanner_install before the plugin actually called it itself. In both case, the execution report is found in the application folder.

To get the coverage info for a test, all the csexe found in the test folder and subfolders need to be merged. This is what is currently done in post-treatment. And this is why for a QTest test TestA, you need to actually select the coverage reports from TestA and tc_TestA to get the actual coverage provided by a TestA. tc_TestA is the coverage info found under TestA folder but not directly associated with TestA in the csexe report. This level of details is not directly reported though in the final html report, it is available &quot;manually&quot; using coverage browser and loading the csmes database. 

But coverage info can be merged to a test only if they are not already associated with another test (like a QTest subtest). &quot;Associated with a test&quot; means that __coveragescanner_testname has been called with a non empty test name and the coverage info is saved under this test name in the csexe report. Also this is only the case for QTest and QtQuickTest based tests with the current implementation.

Subtests of QProcess, QApplication and QClipboard for example are Qt applications but not QTest based tests and that's why their subtests status don't appear in the final report. However, in post-treatment, their coverage info is merged and used.

Selftests subtests are QTest based subtests, and until now a status was reported for them but this was incorrect and this is where this change is useful. 

Does it clarify the point?
|Uploaded patch set 2.
|Patch Set 2:

Yes, this will indeed increase the coverage reported for tst_selftests (The final/global coverage will stay unchanged though). The subprocesses coverage data will be merged with the main test during the post processing steps (qtqa scripts).

And the purpose of this change is also to avoid the QTest subtests to show up in the report. -skipcoverage can be considered as an implementation detail since it is used for one test only for now. It is more accurate though. Using -subtest was a more generic name and could eventually be reused for other purpose if needed at some point, they are subtests after all. If the option must refer to coverage, I would actually rename it something like -subtestForCoverage, what do you think?
|Patch Set 2:

I do like this :) I will test it.

|Patch Set 1:

Only the *.c and *.cpp are shown in the html report. The choice made to not include the header files is arbitrary. While some headers contain inline and/or functions definitions, it is not possible to show only those in this report. While having headers is relevant (and there is a know issue QTQAINFRA-345) I think that having all the headers decreases visibility since most of them don't have code to test for code coverage. This can easily be changed though. What do you think?

|Patch Set 13: (1 inline comment)


|Patch Set 1:

Attempt to solve task QTQAINFRA-345 with including all the HEADERS (not from 3rdparty folder though) in the instrumentation, shows build time and database size issues.

Testcocoon needs to create instrumentation for each header file that contains inline functions and function definitions. This is very slow (build not finished after 1 hour) and the database sizes increase (qtbase size is 90GB after 1 hour).

Removing all the headers from the instrumentation makes the current solution less confusing.
|Patch Set 1:

There are the options --cs-include-path/--cs-exclude path. But the problem was to find for each module the module/src folder.

|Patch Set 1:

Hm, I am not sure why you are getting this message. It worked for me (I added QT_NO_PRINTER in the pro file for testing):

********* Start testing of tst_QPrinterInfo *********
Config: Using QTest library 5.0.0, Qt 5.0.0
SKIP   : tst_QPrinterInfo::initTestCase() This test requires printing support
.\tst_qprinterinfo.cpp(87) : failure location
SKIP   : tst_QPrinterInfo::cleanupTestCase() This test requires printing support
.\tst_qprinterinfo.cpp(92) : failure location
Totals: 0 passed, 0 failed, 2 skipped
********* Finished testing of tst_QPrinterInfo *********

Maybe do you have a qt4 in your path?

&quot;error: macro &quot;QSKIP&quot; requires 2 arguments, but only 1 given&quot;

QSKIP used to have 2 arguments:
http://doc-snapshot.qt-project.org/4.8/qtest.html#QSKIP

Now it has only one:
http://qt-project.org/doc/qt-5.0/qtest.html#QSKIP

Also I will investigate if contains(DEFINES, QT_NO_PRINTER) works and then I could indeed just exclude the test!

|Patch Set 3:

The test is failing on my Mac 10.6 because the folders test and test2 don't appear first in the list. On Mac files order depends on the locale. By renaming the folders ATest and ATest2, the test then passed for me. But we cannot assume this will always work.

Also the non native dialog is tested on other platforms and it is not widely used on Mac.

Thus it is probably better to disable the test on Mac.

The test passed on Ubuntu 11.10.

WIP: This will not work for shadow build.

Memo:

qtdesktop.pro

TEMPLATE = app
TARGET = tst_qtdesktop

testplugin_path = $$PWD/../testplugin
win*: testplugin_path=$$replace(testplugin_path, /, \\)
message($$testplugin_path)
check.commands += (set QML2_IMPORT_PATH=$$testplugin_path) &amp;

|Uploaded patch set 2.
|Patch Set 2:

Attempt to use macro IMPORTPATH

This macro will append the path to the plugin to testrunner.
So when running ${MAKE} check, qmlscene will look in the
specified path too to find plugins. This avoid/replace the need of setting QML2_IMPORT_PATH at run time.

The difficulty is that we need to know the path of the plugin. And here in the plugin I set DESTDIR. This forces in-source build for shadow builds and this is not a long term solution.
|Uploaded patch set 3.
|Uploaded patch set 4.
|Uploaded patch set 5.
|Uploaded patch set 6.
|Patch Set 6: No score

Compatible with $(MAKE) check for both standard and shadow builds.

Maybe in this change could you add?

diff --git a/tests/auto/qpluginloader/tst_qpluginloader.cpp b/tests/auto/qpluginloader/tst_qpluginloader.cpp
index 274496f..ac65d2d 100644
--- a/tests/auto/qpluginloader/tst_qpluginloader.cpp
+++ b/tests/auto/qpluginloader/tst_qpluginloader.cpp
@@ -422,7 +422,7 @@ void tst_QPluginLoader::loadGarbage()
 {
 #if defined (Q_OS_UNIX) &amp;&amp; !defined(Q_OS_SYMBIAN)
     for (int i=0; i&lt;5; i++) {
-        QPluginLoader lib(QString(SRCDIR &quot;elftest/garbage%1.so&quot;).arg(i));
+        QPluginLoader lib(QString(SRCDIR &quot;elftest/garbage%1.so&quot;).arg(i+1));
         QCOMPARE(lib.load(), false);
 #ifdef SHOW_ERRORS
         qDebug() &lt;&lt; lib.errorString();
 
Garbage libraries are numbered from 1 to 5 and not from 0 to 4.

|Patch Set 3:

I was able to reproduce the problem on ubuntu 11.10. by deleting the plugin, checking it out and re-running the test again. The error was:

&quot;Plugin verification data mismatch&quot;

********* Start testing of tst_QPluginLoader *********
Config: Using QTest library 4.7.4, Qt 4.7.4
PASS   : tst_QPluginLoader::initTestCase()
QDEBUG : tst_QPluginLoader::loadCorruptElf() &quot;Plugin verification data mismatch in '/home/caroline/git/qt48/tests/auto/qpluginloader/elftest/corrupt1.elf64.so'&quot; 
FAIL!  : tst_QPluginLoader::loadCorruptElf() 'lib1.errorString().contains(&quot;not a valid Qt plugin&quot;)' returned FALSE. ()
   Loc: [../tst_qpluginloader.cpp(385)]
PASS   : tst_QPluginLoader::cleanupTestCase()
Totals: 2 passed, 1 failed, 0 skipped
********* Finished testing of tst_QPluginLoader *********

It seems the problem is &quot;QPluginLoader checks that a plugin is linked against the same version of Qt as the application.&quot;

In my case, when I run the test a second time, the test is then passing.

This issue is not related to this change. Maybe the plugins need to be build along the test?

|Patch Set 9: No score

I don't have a Mac to test it but looking at qtLibraryTarget in qt48/mkspecs/features/qt_functions.prf,
it seems the plugin gets a debug extension:

defineReplace(qtLibraryTarget) {
   unset(LIBRARY_NAME)
   LIBRARY_NAME = $$1
   mac:!static:contains(QT_CONFIG, qt_framework) {
      QMAKE_FRAMEWORK_BUNDLE_NAME = $$LIBRARY_NAME
      export(QMAKE_FRAMEWORK_BUNDLE_NAME)
   }
   contains(TEMPLATE, .*lib):CONFIG(debug, debug&#124;release) {
      !debug_and_release&#124;build_pass {
          mac:RET = $$member(LIBRARY_NAME, 0)_debug
   	      else:win32:RET = $$member(LIBRARY_NAME, 0)d
      }
   }
   isEmpty(RET):RET = $$LIBRARY_NAME
   return($$RET)
}

Looking at qpluginloader/theplugin/theplugin.pro, they had a related issue and replaced:
# Use a predictable name for the plugin, no debug extension. Just like most apps do.
#TARGET        = $$qtLibraryTarget(theplugin)
TARGET        = theplugin

That should be enough for us here (for info the related change in qtbase is sha1 418890e)
|Patch Set 10: Looks good to me, approved


|Patch Set 2:

Thanks for this change Kai. Could you change quickcontrols to just controls?

The idea is to get the examples into:
examples/quick/controls alongside:

examples/quick/dialogs
examples/quick/window
...

So the structure is consistent with the installation:
qml/QtQuick/Controls
qml/QtQuick/Dialogs
qml/QtQuick/Windows
...

What do you think?
