|Patch Set 1:

Shawn, in qmlplugindump tool, I now excludes the properties/methods starting with &quot;__&quot;. So they won't be available for auto-completion qt Qt Creator:
https://codereview.qt-project.org/#change,64594

Do the prop/methods starting with a single &quot;_&quot; need to be excluded? I thought the double &quot;__&quot; was the rule, but I am not 100% sure now.
|Patch Set 1:

I see the point and I don't disagree. But is that really necessary since in qml you can call a function whatever its access mode? Even if I set the functions access to Private, I can still call them from qml.

Also QMetaMethod has this access flag, but QMetaProperty doesn't if I am correct. So while we can set the access to protected/public for the methods depending on their names, the qmlplugindump tool would still need to check for the &quot;__&quot; when dealing with properties.

It seems that having the right access mode only makes sense in C++ not in qml. So I am just not sure that using the method access is a better approach than using the qmlplugindump tool to identify data available for autocompletion. Anything else I may be missing?

|Patch Set 19:

If you have:

        model: ListModel {
                id: cbItems
                ListElement { text: &quot;Banana&quot;; color: &quot;Yellow&quot; }
                ListElement { text: &quot;Apple&quot;; color: &quot;Green&quot; }
                ListElement { text: &quot;Coconut&quot;; color: &quot;Brown&quot; }
            }
        editable: true
        validator: RegExpValidator {regExp: /[a-zA-z]*/}

Because of autocompletion, you can never enter aaa or bbb because when entering a it is updated to A. 

Enter a then delete, enter a again the Apple appears.
(Entering aaa the first time works though)
|Patch Set 21: (6 inline comments)

Looking good!
One difference with QComboBox is when enter &quot;a&quot;, QComboBox autocomplete with &quot;apple&quot; (lower case a is not changed) and when enter is press, set value to &quot;Apple&quot;. ComboBox completes with &quot;Apple&quot; without pressing enter.

|Uploaded patch set 2.
|Uploaded patch set 3.
|Uploaded patch set 4.
|Uploaded patch set 5.
|Patch Set 5:

The flat style example doesn't work on iOS for 5.5.0 at the moment. I have chosen on purpose to use Q_OS_IOS only here because static builds in general are broken with QtQuick.

QT_QUICK_CONTROLS_STYLE is not documented and I thought it was an internal &quot;hack&quot; until we have in place a nice API to set a non default style at startup :) Using something like &quot;static__Flat__QtQuickExtrasFlatPlugin&quot; was the simplest solution I found to minimize the change, I am not sure how to get the plugin style name otherwise (to use with QPluginLoader)

Using &quot;#ifdef QT_STATIC&quot; is a good idea but does not give us enough info on which plugin to use. 

Note that iOS is not a &quot;common&quot; case for static build because we do ship the qmldir files inside the application bundle, so for iOS we can find them.

In generic static builds, the qmldir are missing and should be included in resources to be found. Andy is currently trying to fix static builds (see https://codereview.qt-project.org/#/c/111866/)

I do agree that this solution is not general enough, this change may just add on more complexity. But we don't have proper static builds and style set-up ready yet and I am not sure what's best to do at this stage. Maybe this is something we can discuss? :)
|Uploaded patch set 6.
|Patch Set 6:

I took into account JP's comments and made the change less iOS specific. Now check if QT_STATIC is defined and figure out the plugin's name based on the style name.

What is specific about the style plugin is that we want to use it instead of the default style. This must happen before any qml file is loaded. We may not even import it in a qml file, thus using QT_IMPORT_PLUGIN manualy is needed.

In the flat example, the example actually use import QtQuick.Controls.Style.Flat but there could be cases where we would load a style without importing it in any qml file. I have added QT_IMPORT_PLUGIN to make it more obvious in the example.

Note: The style plugin here is only used to include qml files in resources, the qmldir is empty. We use qml_plugin.qrf for the only sake of deploying it into a know qml import location.

|Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2
|AFAICT the DEPLOYMENT qmake variable only works on Symbian or Windows CE.

Has this actually been tested on harmattan builds and shown to work?

What is supposed to happen is that either qt3dquick_pkg_dep.pri or qt3d_pkg_dep.pri is supposed to set the icons.files variable to the appropriate value.  Then in pkg.pri icons.path is set and icons itself is added to the INSTALLS var.
|Will this apostrophe terminate the string started at '&lt;br&gt; on line 85, and cause a syntax error, or other problem?
|Suggest avoiding the double-negative:

    This is useful in the case where multiple cameras are used.
|What will happen when the scene is first rendered and the fbo has not yet had any content rendered into it?  Or is it colour filled or something?

Do you get a recursion thing happening?  If this is still an open issue maybe restructure the example to avoid dealing with it right now.  Otherwise make some mention of it.
|This file looks like its been checked in mistakenly.

This directory &quot;Qt3DQuick&quot; does not exist in my source control, and I think it is created by the syncqt process, so its a generated file.

This is most likely caused as a result of not doing shadow builds, so therefore build artefacts have gotten into your check in.
|Unfortunately this is already the name of a class from QML: try googling for QDeclarativeAnimation and you'll see what I mean.

Suggest using a similar name that has the string &quot;3D&quot; in it somewhere.
|Since this function does not need any member or class information, it does not even need to be a static member.

Suggest it just be:

    static inline qNotifyItemsRecursive(QQuickItem* pItem, QOpenGLContext* pContext)
    {
        // implementation
    }

See &quot;Prefer non-member non-friend functions&quot; Effective C++ 3rd Ed by Meyers Item 23, Pg 98 for more.
|Is this level argument actually used for anything?  Maybe it was used in debug printout, but I don't see it used at present.
|See comment in .cpp file about removing this from the header, and making this just a local helper.
|This macro logic looks a bit brittle.  Suggest some more parens, or break it up over more lines.
|Comment style should match the rest of the file.
|whitespace!
|Maybe we should just make all of these

   directory: [&quot;qml&quot;]

Since we should never have any qml files or attendant resources in the directory above the qml directory.  Except for the wrapper anyway.

Removing an element from this list means that load times are quicker because the search is not stat'ing and checking as much.  I suggest trying an strace of the two options to see the difference.
|In the more general case we should in Qt5 be using signal spy for this.  Doc is in

    qtdeclarative/src/imports/testlib/signalspy.qdoc

for getting things ported over and working, yes just do what is needed.  Longer term signal spy is better than creating all these properties ourselves.
|OK, this is a reasonable start to the rotation, but in the original app you could set a rotation value for X, Y or Z independently.

This is termed Euler angles, and is a popular way of doing this, even though it results in gimbal lock.

This ability to only set one angle and choose one of the three axes seems to be missing something.
|Suggest a brief comment explaining what this limit switch does.  Since ValueField is a re-useable component, this effectively forms part of the API of it, and &quot;limit&quot; doesn't really tell you.
|Maybe its because of the awkward ternary operator?

In any case you could just require that ValueFields *always* have a label.  This seems reasonable.

Even more reasonable, when you note that the only field in the app when you run it that does not have a label is scale, and in fact you should be able to scale differently in the X, Y and Z directions.

In the original modelviewer from the research repo, you could click a &quot;lock&quot; button to make the scale values all move together or change independently.

Why exactly is it denied to the user to be able to change the X, Y and Z scale?
|This comment could be more informative that the x 1 is actually doing a &quot;javascript string to int cast&quot;
|Suggest some more comments here.

Explain which is the top-left, top-right and bottom-right viewports, and what aspect of the model they are displaying.

Generally these code files are a bit light on comments.
|Back-tab doesn't work.  That is I can tab forward through the fields but the only way to get back to a previous field is I have to take my fingers off the keyboard and use the mouse.
|These controls look good and have improved the UI quite a bit.

The values in the fields fill up with far too much precision size.  This makes the resulting value hard to read and difficult to assess as you increase or decrease.
|At some point this needs to be made more modular and setup for unit testing.

Its OK as a start.
|The brace for the opening of this function should be on the next line, I think.  The Qt coding style guide agrees with me:

http://doc.qt.nokia.com/qtcreator-extending/coding-style.html#braces
|As per sanity bot this should be

    if (!file.open(....))
|Its not just about display - QML also uses these for updating values that are derived from this.  So if you have some javascript which does something programatically with the value of filename, then it won't pick up any changed value, AFAICT.

It might not matter, right now, but the proper notify signals should be added otherwise there will probably be hard to diagnose bugs down the track.
|Not so important since this is a desktop application, but the umbrella includes pull in a lot of headers that are not needed.  As a rule just use the headers that are needed.
|Still seeing this disembodied camera text in the UI which does not seem to relate to anything.
|This blank effect seems to result in the target app in the model losing its materials.

Suggest leaving this out of the generated QML, and app developers can add it in to a outer scope if needed
|This is quite distracting - I get all my fields &quot;selected&quot; - that is highlighted in blue - when I tab through.

Obviously only the one with focus gets edited, but it is hard to see which one has the focus with all highlighted.

Also - as sanity bot points out below should be

   onFocusChanged: if (focus == true) selectAll(); else select(0,0)

or even better:

    onFocusChanged: {
        if (focus) {
            selectAll();
        } else {
            select(0,0);
        }
    }
|This seems to work around your &quot;no negative values in the scale&quot; logic, so dragging the mouse with middle button pressed results in negative values.

As sanity bot says these should have a space.

     else if (mouseDown === Qt.MiddleButton)

I do like the pattern of wrapping the onMouseXChanged: handler in curly braces tho, rather than squeezing if &amp; else on one line.
|Something a bit more traditional in the way of titles for help dialogs would be good:

    s/Apparently you're having problems/ModelTweaker Help/

&quot;&lt;app title&gt; Help&quot;  for example.
|s/dragging with/dragging will/
|These changes are not reflected in the commit messages.

What do they do?
|I think you want 

    QFileDialog::getSaveFileName(...) 

...since this one does not allow you to type in a name to save the file under.  You can only save it over an already existing filename.
|The grey-on-grey is a bit tough on the tired eyes.  The black text becomes hard to read.

Needs a bit of color.  Suggest searching the internet for some good UI color schemes.  Orange or &quot;burly wood&quot; might work for button background color.
|Hmm - this code looks a bit brittle, with the use of QUrl here, and its confusing (by which I mean it could use some more inline doco to explain what it is supposed to do).

I suspect you might need to do

    QFileInfo fi(_filename);
    QString modelFileName = fi.canonicalFilePath();

...since with the other one you don't know for sure if its absolute, you could get a relative path there.

Ok, so basically you just use the _filename to get the location of the current file so you can make a relative path to it.

So you probably want to put that into your getSaveFileName dialog as the third argument.

Also - with coding style again:  I prefer 

    QString m_filename;

This is fine, as long as its consistent in the app.
|OK - so the lock image is added but not wired up yet?

Might want to mention that in the submit message.
|Not sure why this line was removed.
|Maybe:

     valueSlider.update(text)
|It's actually now 

    	https://qt.gitorious.org/qt/quick3d

...should change it.
|This looks sufficient for the method documentation.

You should mention the need for the context to be current and the fact that if its not a warning is printed.

Suggest maybe mentioning this in the class level documentation.

We can improve documentation in a second pass.
|You can also use the qPrintable() macro for this.  But this is fine.
|This looks OK - can also look at void QSGPainterNode::updateGeometry() where the InvertedYFramebufferObject is set.  Same sort of approach.

I guess since you have your own QSGGeometry subclass you'll always have to track what ever changes SG does underneath your FBO usage.
|I wonder if seeking back to 0 is correct here.  What if the device was at some offset in say a zip file stream?

I guess the original code assumes 0 anyway, so it is at least better than that.  Let's go with this, and see how unit tests on all platforms go via CI.

|Change has been successfully cherry-picked to the staging branch as 6b09eb2c674cb96287c54006c6f774e4aecc8a38.
|Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(3 inline comments)

This is a good start.  It's good to do it in QML as far as possible, and the structure looks good.

However I strongly suggest that to go back and just try to get one of the use cases working properly - that is with numerical entry, slider and dragging in the viewport, all linked together.  Just having numerical entry seems wrong, and the way the dragging does not change the display is confusing.

Maybe rotation would be a good place to start.  You could have 3 sliders for rotation around each of the 3 axes, or maybe knobs.  If you drag the model, it moves the sliders, and updates the numbers; and vice-versa.

When it comes to position, you could have a mode change - eg holding down control and dragging, or sliding the sliders, makes the position get updated.  You could have a mode indicator on the display so that when you depress the control key it switches from &quot;rotation&quot; to &quot;position&quot;.
|Uploaded patch set 2.
|Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, approved; Sanity review passed

Already reviewed.  Just fixing merge conflict.

(1 inline comment)

The 3 pane view is effective enough as far as it goes.

|Change has been successfully cherry-picked to the staging branch as 18f50cccdd67c161bebf9f5be12164e105e18a71.
|Patch Set 2: (4 inline comments)

This looks really good from a functionality point of view, succinct and gets the job done.

Suggest to address the review comments and make a new patchset.

Also I recommend thinking ahead to when this could be unit tested, and put the functionality in to .cpp file, so that you have room to add documentation for the function signatures.

This will help when you get to writing unit tests.  For example, what will happen if the filename is set to the null string?  If the answer is &quot;behavior is undefined&quot; then you get to say that, rather than just getting the default of whatever the QFile::open(...) function happens to do with an empty string.
|Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, approved; Sanity review passed

|Change has been successfully cherry-picked to the staging branch as b475a4850786cff1e599ae35ed7ce7cee84cecbd.
|Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, approved

Better for other systems than linux.  :-)
|Patch Set 1:

Looking back at this there are a couple of clunky things with the writing of the file that should have been picked up in earlier reviews.  The right way to write out a text file is to open a QTextStream:

    QFile qmlFile(fileName);
    if (qmlFile.open(QIODevice::WriteOnly))
    {
        QTextStream os(&amp;qmlFile);
        os &lt;&lt; data;
        qmlFile.close():
    }

Also the line where debug output is done:

    qDebug(&quot;This was the file name %s&quot;, qPrintable(fileName));

or better:

    qDebug() &lt;&lt; &quot;This was the file name:&quot; &lt;&lt; fileName;

This last one needs to be protected by 

    #ifndef QT_NO_DEBUG_STREAM
    // ...
    #endif

|Change has been successfully cherry-picked to the staging branch as b745901e607ba8cb4548a1f51ca77ee2a7b9b710.
|Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

The commit message should look like:

    QGLSceneNode recursive child-node cloning

    Task-number: QTBUG-23299

So there *has* to be a short summary (less than 72 characters) with a blank line immediately after, and then when you quote the bug number it *must* be in the funky special format as shown, including the colon, and one space after it.

See this one for example:  http://codereview.qt-project.org/11578

Notice how gerrit turns the QTBUG into a hyperlink, whilst the one above is not.
|Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, approved

|Change has been successfully cherry-picked to the staging branch as 1fc3d7d52666f318c83251c307b23f6ebe737b35.
|Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, approved

OK, sure - but folks should not be building inside the source checkout.

http://doc-snapshot.qt-project.org/qt3d-1.0/qt3d-building.html - shadow building is always preferred.

There is a never-ending list of build artefacts that changes every time some detail of the build alters, and this approach is always going to be playing catchup.

|Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)


|Uploaded patch set 4.
|Patch Set 4:

explicitSizeValue -&gt; explicitViewSizeValue
|Patch Set 4: Abandoned

This would be convenient but also raises a number of issues. For example, the user would probably expect the contentItem to automatically resize for any future change to childrenRect, which is unnecessarily expensive. Also, once contentWidth/Height is explicitly changed, then the Flickable should no longer automatically resize to its children, but this change in behaviour may be confusing. It seems better for the user to explicitly set up and tear down any necessary bindings in this case.

|Patch Set 2:

Changes since the patch in animation-refactor:
- Fixed crash when accessing ViewTransition.item without starting the relevant transition
- Fixed QQuickItemViewPrivate::transitionNextReposition() to cancel running transitions to fix item layout issues when e.g. the add transition was set but not the addDisplaced transition
- Fixed to use populate transition on model reset
- Fixed to not move removed items to (0,0)
- Removed stray debugs
- Removed most duplicate code from tests
- Renamed QQuickItemViewTransition -&gt; QQuickViewTransitionAttached
- Fixed tests to also test ViewTransition.item
- Updated whatsnew.qdoc

|Patch Set 16:

Moved all content from qml/doc/new into qml/doc/src and moved qml/doc/new/main.qdoc to qml/doc/src/qtqml.qdoc to become the new module index page. The same has been done for qtquick. However the index pages still have to be fixed to correctly refer to the C++ class lists.

Some content still has to be merged into the new documentation. These have been placed into todo/ directories. (Some of this content has been partially merged already.)

|Patch Set 5:

As discussed, the built examples don't run on Mac since the .qml files are not accessible to the executable. Maybe it's worth going with the qrc solution since that's what we've done with some of the examples (e.g. modelviews/abstractitemmodel).

We could stow the the .qrc, main.cpp and launcher .qml files in a separate subdirectory (e.g. animation_launcher?) to avoid clutter. I suppose this might be an appropriate location for the .qdoc file as well if we end up needing to put that in a separate file.

|Patch Set 3:

Ok, I can move these to testconfig.

About having one template for whole qt5 packaging, currently we have the packaging splitted to smaller steps: src package, binary build and installer creation. The benefit of that is that we can re-build just the binaries or just the installer, which will save lot of time. Afaik we would like to keep it that way (unless Iikka has other opinion) which will require several templates for Jenkins.

|Patch Set 2:

I thinks it's more clear when they are in different files (one ini file for defining the jobs and other for defining the nodes to build the jobs), the file size doesn't grow so big making it easier to find when you need to update something.

So, unless this structure is very unpractical and unusefull I would like to keep it this way. But if the common opinion is that it's better have just one ini file, I'll combine these.

|removeFirst() does not return the list but otherwise a working solution.
|Preferably I would like the 'old' implementation back to QProcess, that in Windows you could start process with empty arguments when using setNativeArguments().
|Thanks Kai. 
Do you have suggestions how this should be fixed? As cmd.exe requires the use of setNativeArguments(), we cannot pass the parameters in QProcess::start().

From QProcess::start() doc:
&quot;Windows: The arguments are quoted and joined into a command line that is compatible with the CommandLineToArgvW() Windows function. For programs that have different command line quoting requirements, you need to use setNativeArguments(). One notable program that does not follow the CommandLineToArgvW() rules is cmd.exe and, by consequence, all batch scripts.&quot;

Should we allow calling setNativeArguments() directly from script before execute -operation?
|This is better, but it still gives a warning if another installer with the same name is started (not the same installer) because now  all installers uses the same lock file. However, the warning is only seen in when run verbose because of this runchec.isRunning check here. I don't mind this as this solution is way better than it was before, but I would change the the comment above this as it is no longer valid.
|ah, there is an assert when trying to set model to item based itemview.
|Otherwise looks good, but should we check here if the QAbstractitemView is item based? As if you set model to for example QListWidget, then this will probably crash.
|True, that would happen if the throw was catched. But this should be done in a different commit as it is not related to this fix, errors are thrown also elsewhere in this method.
|This is callback for download for the compressed item, it is not decompressed yet. In this method we start the decompress task for downloaded compress file.
|I was trying to keep the changes consistence, this is how it is done also in the parseUpdatesXml() method. If warning is wanted instead of debug then we need to change it to the other place too in a different commit.
|This is also for consistence, checkout above method
|Yes. But what  should the text itself actually be? Not very good to say 'repositories/files'
|No. Other command line parser error messages are not tr() either. If that is wanted, then separate commit to fix all.

|Uploaded patch set 3.
|Uploaded patch set 4.
|Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)

Normally the repository items are not compressed. As bsp packages are, they need to be decompressed first. So what we do here is that we download the compressed file and decompress it to temp folder. If we don't decompress in this stage, installer does not notice if there are updates available. Note that the content is not decompressed yet.
After that the bsp repository install happens like in 'normal' repository package - when the actual install begins, we decompress the content.
|Patch Set 4:

Ok, now I get it. As the package cannot be downloaded from server we don't need to download it to tmp folder and decompress it from there. Instead we can extract it from where it was downloaded already.

|Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1
|The unstable test function always seems to be QSKIP'ed in CI (at least in pulse run ranges 730-829 and 870-969). So the instability is unproblematic to CI. In other execution environments, the problem might still arise, so QTBUG-21100 still applies on those cases. Haven't reproduced it myself, though.
|Whitespace-only change that seems to be irrelevant to the overall change.
|Whitespace-only change that seems to be irrelevant to the overall change.
|Whitespace-only change that seems to be irrelevant to the overall change.
|This case is already handled in findPartitionDefinitions() (a list with a single item is returned). findPartitionDefinitions() returns an empty list to indicate an unrecoverable error condition.
|How can it fail? If defaultSpecified is true at this point, it is set as a result of the current partition being marked as default, so it should be fine to reset defaultSpecified to false. (More precisely: if defaultSpecified was true because of an earlier partition, the current partition wouldn't be allowed to be default (see code path a few lines above), so we wouldn't even enter this if-block in the first place.)

I agree with Rohan. The '#include &lt;...&gt;' form seems to be far more common than '#include &quot;...&quot;' for Qt headers (private as well as public) in both tests and in the Qt source itself. I guess it ought to be a coding style convention (if it isn't already).

|Patch Set 1:

&gt; 1) Reasons for putting INSTALLS rule in a central *.pri file
&gt;    if I forget to copy/paste the install rule, my test won't be run, and I might think that everything is OK.

This could be automatically checked and warned about.
|Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Tick counts can be thought of as a high resolution alternative to the default QTimer-based measurer. Both are sensitive to the same system instabilities (both include system calls - in contrast to callgrind). I can't see any problems using a minimum accumulated time of 50 milliseconds for both. (Note that callgrind should still accept any measurement (i.e. always return true in isMeasurementAccepted()) since it is expected to generate the same number when repeated).

I would still like to check with Morten Sorvig - the original integrator of the CPU ticks feature.

|Patch Set 1:

Note that this is a two-step move operation. The first commit deletes qtipc from qtbase while the second commit re-introduces qtipc in qtscript.

The second commit must await final merge of the first commit so that it can refer to the SHA-1 in the commit message.

|Patch Set 1:

Note that the whitespace issues reported by the sanity bot were already present in this code when it lived in qtbase, so the overall amount of trailing/leading whitespace in Qt does not increase by this change.

I suggest we ignore them for now and instead clean them up later together with whitespace issues elsewhere.

I am not sure why we had geocodemodel in mapviewer.qml. Previously MapComponent provided geocodemodel and pointdelegate as well, so we had a circle representing our point. |Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

This fix proposal doesn't take into account that there is no ShapeBounding defined on Solaris. And it also fails if -no-xshape option is set in configure.

With -no-xshape set, one gets these errors:
&quot;kernel/qdnd_x11.cpp&quot;, line 1429: Error: The function &quot;XShapeGetRectangles&quot; must have a prototype.
&quot;kernel/qdnd_x11.cpp&quot;, line 1472: Error: ShapeBounding is not defined.
2 Error(s) and 5 Warning(s) detected.

There needs to be a check for #if defined QT_NO_XSHAPE around the windowInteractsWithPosition() function.

The implementation there is at the moment is working on Solaris, but #if defined QT_NO_XSHAPE must be added around the function mentioned previously, since the proposed fix hasn't been tested with -no-xshape, it would fail if XShape is not available.
|Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Sorry for mixing things. There indeed is ShapeBounding defined on Solaris.

This fix compiles on Solaris (and Fedora also) and I can approve it. :)
|Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

This doesn't brake anything I have tested :)

void tst_QQuickWebEngineView::basicRenderingSanity()
{
    showWebEngineView();

    webEngineView()-&gt;setUrl(QUrl(QString::fromUtf8(&quot;data:text/html,&lt;html&gt;&lt;body bgcolor=\&quot;#00ff00\&quot;&gt;&lt;/body&gt;&lt;/html&gt;&quot;)));

                                                      [testColor] (const QImage &amp;image) {
        return image.pixel(10, 10) == testColor;

|Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1
|Patch Set 14:

|Change has been successfully cherry-picked to the staging branch.
|Should all other metadata values be converted with toString before inserting to object?
|Uniqueness to access constraints instead of hard coding
|Detail field not detail type
|I'd prefer MissingMandatoryDeetailFieldError
|I'm asking to create clear rules about when an item (or collection) is valid, documenting them and also changing the implementation to reflect the rules. I don't think rules should contain anything which requires cross-checking between items, such as checking if a collection really exists in data base or checking if the parent of an occurrence really exists.
|What does a valid item mean in the context of this function? Is of supported item type, has only supported detail types, contains all mandatory fields, cardinality of details is correct? Some cross-checking between detail fields: if one field is present then the other must be too? Something else?
|qCritical could be added to explain what requirement is missing.
|I don't like having friendship between request thread and engine. I also think maybe this whole check could be removed from this function, because this kind of cross-referencing checks are done when handling save request and remove request (and maybe could be added to fetch requests too). Or if we check that the collection really exists, should we also check for occurrences that the parent item really exists, etc? We need to scope validation functions carefully and also document that.
|Should we utilize here supportedItemTypes function?
|It might be a good idea to use supportedItemDetails to find out allowed details for a item type instead of hard coding them. Also mandatoriness and uniqueness information would be nice to have in a table where it would be easy to read and maintain. However, in this function performance is the priority, so some hardcoding is ok if it's more efficient than using tables and functions...
|Detail field can be mandatory and it of course implies that a detail can also be mandatory, but should the error code be rather MissingMandatoryDetailFieldError?
|Validation of a collection or an item should be possible without accessing the data base and checking the items there. Validation should only be about the &quot;format&quot; of the collection, no cross-checking between collections in data base and the collections which is being validated. Otherwise it would be really hard to draw the line, which part of the validation belongs to validate function and which part to handling of save request. E.g. in item save request there is a huge amount of different cross-checks between items, parent items, and collections, which really cannot be part of the validation function.
|This check could be removed from this function and added to handling of collection save request.
|Yep, there should not be any qDebugs in the code.
|For validation when fetching: fetch occurrence request sometimes fetches items from db (if include exceptions flag is true in internalOccurrences function). Fetch by id request does not use internalItems function, instead it accesses m_storage directly, so it needs to be handled separately.
|I don't like this friendship, please see more comments in jsondb engine class.
|Please read the comments for the previous patch. updateMaxItemsCount should not be called from this function. maxItemCountChanged should be connected to doUpdateItems slot. There is no reason to invent new mechanism for checking autoUpdate, because we already have doUpdateItems function where it is done.
|Good points. I considered making the whole class static, but decided not to because then all functions in the class (also private) would have had to be static... I keep it in mind and maybe change them in the future.
|The value of the string should be upper case (&quot;ANNIVERSARY&quot;), if we want to follow http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5545#page-147, see 5.7.
|Property declarations should be the first thing in the object (because this object does not have id). Signal declarations should be right after them.
|Delete functionality could be moved to event edit page.
|Done in &quot;Adapt organizer to the new QtJsonDb API&quot; patch.
|Done in &quot;Adapt organizer to the new QtJsonDb API&quot; patch.
|Done in &quot;Adapt organizer to the new QtJsonDb API&quot; patch.
|Some typos in this sentence?
|The order of parameters could be the same as in c++: start, end, maxCount, sortOrders (not sortList), fetchHint, storageLocation.
|Another fetchItems function without start and end dates might be useful, if the user does not want to give any time limit, but wants to use e.g. filters. Even this does not support the case where only start or end date should be set...
|Note that this method of cleaning up the model does not handle recurring events correctly. QOrganizerTestUtility.empty_calendar  handles also recurring items. Probably in this case it does not matter because there are no recurring items in the test data.

- Different abbreviations for Qt Personal Information Management have been used: QtPIM, QtPim and Qt PIM. I would suggest having Qt Pim if abbreviation is needed.

- I would prefer 'QML List View' instead of 'Qt Quick List View'

|Patch Set 7: (5 inline comments)

I think this overview provides a lot of good stuff, and I think this works for the beta, but I still think it can be improved before the final release. E.g. I question a bit the areas we are highlighting. I don't know what the correct list should be, but 

- should we really be highlighting e.g. JSON DB here?  
- perhaps modularization and its benefits deserve a separate heading?
- do we have other highlights that are worth mentioning?

Also I think we should not forget to mention the general benefits of Qt, or at least link to them. People who read this might never have used Qt before, and therefore are interested in hearing about Qt's cross-platform benefits etc. Not sure if you somehow can start with the general benefits of Qt, and then move to what is new and better in Qt 5 compared to Qt 4.x.?

|Patch Set 2:

I noticed that QHeaderView::moveSection() has
if (stretchLastSection() &amp;&amp;  to == d-&gt;lastVisibleVisualIndex())
        d-&gt;lastSectionSize = sectionSize(from);

It strongly suggests that the last section is intentionally not stretched when the section is moved to the last visible position. I don't know the reason behind this, and therefore I am wondering if we should not change the behaviour in moveSection() after all. Thorbjorn, what do you think?

swapSection() doesn't have similar code snippet.

|It's according to the comment at init-repository:568:

```
$module = $gd;  # We expect it to be always absolute.
```

But my old checkout of qt5 has relative path in .gitdir for some submodules. For example, for qtdocgallery.
|Explain please.
|All qt5's submodules is located in top-level folder, therefore .gitdir is always located in /path/to/qt5/&lt;submodule&gt;/.gitdir.

In case of absolute path we do nothing with that. But in case of relative path, .gitdir file will always look like:

```

$ cat qtdocgallery/.git

gitdir: ../.git/modules/qtdocgallery

```

When processing git_install_hooks, working dir is '/path/to/qt5' so the real path we want is '/path/to/qt5/.git/modules/qtdocgallery'.

But here, on lines 578-579 we just adding '/hooks/commit-msg' to the $module path, and so we are failing to get '$PWD/../.git/modules/qtdocgallery/hooks/commit-msg' because the '/path/to/qt5/../.git' directory doesn't exist.

Obviously solutions are:

1. Change working directory to submodule dir

2. (my choice) cut the leading '..' in $module path
|Now I see. You suggest to pass a submodule name as the second argument of rel2abs. But it's the same thing! My way is just cut the '../' off. Your way is rel2abs(&lt;submodule&gt;/../*).
|Unfortunately it will not work because we are not in submodule directory.

|Patch Set 2:

regarding your last comment: you would think that to be the case but in fact it was never so. Yes it was taken into consideration during layout, but then it failed during paint where it was assumed to be 0. In order to avoid nasty source code incompatibilities I don't think we should change behaviour, (other than to make sure it layouts the right width)
It's much cleaner to have a new dedicated method to do what never worked before, rather than changing behaviour.
|Uploaded patch set 3.
|Patch Set 2: (3 inline comments)


|Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

Well apart from the fact that the current API (which isn't documented) doesn't work, no then I can't give any other use cases, but please read my answer to you comment where i analyse why it may be smart to create a new api
|Uploaded patch set 4.
|Patch Set 4:

You asked for a use case where the old &quot;API&quot; wouldn't suffice.

Well think of RTL text. For RTL you only change the width not the x to achieve the indentation. So effectively the tab offset doesn't work for Rtl text.

And this is assuming we still wanted to fix the bug that prevents the current &quot;API&quot; from working
|Patch Set 4:

I'm sorry but this does not make sense. You are basically proposing that both mine and Esben's idea should be implemented.

And fair enough that you are okay with the behavioral change. But you should know that there may be much source code out there that set the position before layouting. because today it doesn't matter. With this behavioral change we are forcing them to change their code, which might be quite complex.

As for indentation it would have to be a per line property, as how else would Qt know what is just a random width and what is a width made smaller by indent.

So now we should use my method (the indent property aka tab offset) when RtL text. And Esbens method (the x value) when LtR text. So x should not have a influence when RtL. and line indent should not have influence when LtR. Sorry but this is even worse.

You mention weird tab and indentation interaction, but I must inform you that odf handles this interaction in two different modes so we need to support both. A toolkit that locks us into one mode is not usable for us.

Please I've been thinking this through for half a year now.

Oh and no tabs are actually moved in my solution. It's only happening during layout based on the offset.
|Patch Set 4:

If memory footprint is the concern i guess we could just store integer values in a short int (rather than a 4byte QFixed)

Since the class already contains a short this would just bring the total memory up to a 4 byte alignment. On many systems this will mean that the footprint hasn't grown.
|Patch Set 4:

No I didn't misunderstand. I do use line x position to achieve indentation. The problem is that the code I moved have no effect on tab positioning (or rather it probably has an effect during layout but when drawing to screen it hasn't)

So i removed the code that uses line.x because:
 1) it made the layout at odds with what is drawn. but sure the drawing could probably be fixed. But my point here is that since it doesn't work today it may give nasty surprises to other users that can't easily adapt their code to such a drastic behavioral change.
 2) using line.x doesn't work for indentation of RtL text. For RtL text indentation is achieved by making the width smaller, however there is no way for the layout to know why the line is made less wide.

So using line.x position to do tabs (like in the non-working  thing i removed) will screw the RtL text users in this world.

Thus my conclusion is that the only way to support RtL is to introduce a per line value.

Pros:
1) It the simplest thing.
2) It works for RtL.
3) It doesn't change current behavior unless you set the value

Cons:
1) It takes another 4 bytes (maybe none if you do as i suggested though it's less nice imo)

Ps. with the acceptance of http://codereview.qt-project.org/#change,12744 I need to update this patch but will do so tonight.
|Patch Set 4:

Actually I've looked and tested and this patch doesn't need updating due to that other patch being merged

Ping, any response on this? The qt5 freeze is getting closer. I hope you are not refusing to rethink this issue, because then Calligra will have to fork Qt text. We can not have a word processor that can't support something as basic as tabs :(

|Patch Set 1:

Note: I'm pretty sure this is correct.

I've tested this in some constellation, and neither early nor double free or a leak occured.

A more formal point of view:

1. new QDomTextPrivate(...) generates t with ref = 1
2. parent()-&gt;insertAfter(t, this); increases ref
3. QDomText::splitText, QDomText(t) increases ref again. (QDomNode::QDomNode constructor)

Thus final reference count is three, while only two references exist, ergo the reference needs to be decremented by one, which this patch does.
|Patch Set 1:

Tests in tests/auto/xml/dom/qdom pass, yes.

Totals: 147 passed, 0 failed, 0 skipped
********* Finished testing of tst_QDom *********

|Patch Set 1:

See QTBUG-40561 it contains a minimal example demonstrating the bug.
|Patch Set 1:

As a memory leak entirely related to incorrect reference counting and not caused by defects in an internal data structure I'd say one could create a test case for this checking the reference counts.

However, no such test cases exist for any other operation (I've checked that, nowhere in the QtXML tests the refcounts are accessed or asserted). Adding tests for each operation modifying reference counts would be quite an amount of test cases... to say the least.

|Patch Set 1:

I don't know, I use Qt4.8. I know there isn't Cleanlooks style in Qt5. This bug appers when the style is changed to Cleanlooks, because height of listview items in this style more than in the other styles.
But in Qt5 sources I see that the list of all widgets is QWidgetSet too, therefore, QEvent::StyleChange may be sent to QComboBoxListView earlier to QComboBox, and the delegate will be updated later than new positions of listview items will be calculated.
Thus, even if this bug doesn't appear in the standard styles of Qt5, it's fraught for custom styles.
|Patch Set 1:

This bug appears not always. Only when QComboBoxListView is before than QComboBox in the list of all widge (QWidgetSet), i.e. when the pointer &quot;this&quot; of QComboBoxListView less than the pointer &quot;this&quot; of QComboBox.
I work on Linux too.
Excuse me, did you try one or more times?
I think, you need to do:
1) run styles example
2) change style to Cleanlooks
3) open combobox and check rendering of listview items
4) close application
and repeat these steps several times (for example, about 10).
|Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated
|Patch Set 1:

In both cases, close() or quit(), function QWindow::destroy() is called and native underlying window (QEglFSWindow, in this case) is deleted. But after that destructor of QSurface (second base class for QWindow) is called. And there doneCurrent() for current opengl context, and therefore eglMakeCurrent(), is called. But surface has been deleted, and we are trying to work with wrong pointer to surface. I have checked it by adding debug to gbm in function dri_flush_front_buffer and I have seen that we have deleted pointer to surface (QEglFSKmsIntegration::destroyNativeWindow() --&gt; gbm_surface_destroy) and after that we have tried to work with the same pointer in eglMakeCurrent.

Execuse me, where is doneCurrent() is called in case of &quot;quit()&quot;?
And what about the opengl examples using just QWindow, not QOpenGLWindow: opengl/hellowindow, opengl/paintedwindow, gui/openglwindow, wayland/qwindow-compositor?

|Thanks for the review. I will add event.setChild(index) since it needs to notify about the name change for the child.

Regarding &quot;checks for that the value is actually changed is preferred&quot;, the name is stored in QTabBarPrivate::Tab. When the accessible name gets retrieved by a client, the name stored in QTabBarPrivate::Tab will be returned through tabAccessibleName() in QAccessibleTabBar::text() or QAccessibleTabButton::text(). So there doesn't seem to be a need to check if the value is actually changed. Can you let me know if I have missed anything?

|Change has been successfully cherry-picked to the staging branch.
|Patch Set 1:

As described in QTBUG-46530, some users don't want to set a simple text for a tab, but rather use setTabButton() to set a customized wiget on the tab. In this case, since the text is empty, screen readers get the empty name of a tab and are unable to annonce the name due to the empty name. Adding the APIs enable users to set accessibleName in case users don't want to set texts for tabs. Hope I made it clear.
|Patch Set 1:

(5 comments)

Can you please let me know if you are referring to the widget set on the tab? If so, since users can call QTabBar::setTabButton() to set two widgets on the left or right hand side of a tab depending on the specified position, it would be confusing to decide which widget's text should be used for accessibleName. If I misunderstood your comments, please let me know:-)

|Uploaded patch set 2.
|Patch Set 2:

(22 comments)

@Friedemann It appears that the existing code assumes all drives returned by QDir::drives() are valid and readable. Some of the mapped network drives returned by QDir::drives() are disconnected and not accessible. Since the exisiting code assumes the drives returned by QDir::drives() are readable, it calls blocking I/O functions such as GetFileAttributesEx() on disconnected mapped network drives to get attributes of those drives, which is the main cause of QTBUG-6039. This patch does the following: detect mapped network drives and connection status of the mapped drives, and the QFileInfo code now don’t call the blocking I/O functions on disconnected mapped drives, which fixes QTBUG-6039. QDir::drives() now returns local drives and all existing mapped network drives on a system. But the patch doesn’t yet provide APIs in QFileInfo for checking if a drive is a mapped network drive, if a mapped drive is connected, etc.  The APIs can be added later. 
Regarding adding the functionality in QStorageInfo() instead, I haven’t studied QStorageInfo yet. How is QStorageInfo used in the existing code? Do QFileDialog or related classes use QStorageInfo?

@Oswald The only change in QFileInfo is to make QFileInfoPrivate a friend class of QFileInfo. Could you elaborate your concerns?
